An heartfelt puzzle-platform game which finds its strength in its collectable educational videos.
Maybe I'm biased because I love learning about other people's cultures, especially those very far from mine, like in this case the indigenous people of Northern Alaska, the Iñupiaq. This game was made entirely by indigenous people and you can tell they really wanted to share their culture with the rest of the world.
Many ideas are great, like the narrator speaking in the Iñupiaq language, using one of their folklore tales as the main source for the narrative (this is done in both the main game and its DLC with another tale) and mixing it with other customs and traditional legends.
Unfortunately, the game has a few bugs and its gameplay it's rather simplistic and at times frustrating due to its camera and controls.
One may be wondering why making it a videogame rather than a documentary instead: I don't know if they thought this was the most immersive way to enter their world or whatever, but somehow they made it enjoyable. 3/5

In short: Overall a positive experience, but it has some frustrating issues.

Positive:
+ [b]It's cute[/b]. The girl and the fox are adorable. They have good chemistry with the little interactions and how they depend on each other.
+ [b]Culture[/b]. A game about a culture you usually don't explore in media. I like that.
+ [b]Short size.[/b] That's usually not a positive, but I think any longer and the frustrations I have with the game would be taking away the fun. So it's mercifully short with about 3 hours and doesn't outstay its welcome.

Negative:
- [b]Janky controls.[/b] Damn, the game is pretty easy, but the janked up controls are responsible for 90% of your deaths. Also if you combine that with having to rely on physics and momentum to get through a platforming puzzle, then it's just plain frustrating. Imagine going through a whole platforming section and the damn fox commits suicide by jumping off a cliff, forcing you to do everything from start.
- [b]Meh story.[/b] The story is okay, but really nothing to write home about. Pretty predictable.
- [b]Repetitive mechanics.[/b] A lot of the puzzles, platforming and so on is repeated quite a lot. It's getting stale over time. I like that the mechanics get shaken up in the second half of the game, [spoiler]when the fox dies and gets turned into a spirit boy. The puzzles get more 3D with one more dimension and his flying ability opens up more possibilities.[/spoiler] 
- [b]Some bugs.[/b] Having to restart from last checkpoint, because the cut scene doesn't start or getting launched 200 meters into the air with Mach 3.

If you want a game of the same genre, but executed better, try Inside.

139647675.review:
This is definitely one of those times where I wish Steam had a neutral response for recommendation. I say that because the game itself isn't all that enjoyable and feels like it's getting in the way of what I actually want to be doing - learning about another culture.

First thing - if you're having problems with 'Never Alone' automatically switching back to Co-Op controls even when you're trying to play single player, do yourself a favor and create a small text file named "autoexec.cfg" in the game's root folder ("/steamapps/common/NeverAlone/") and fill it with the following two lines:

wait 20
inputmode 2

This should fix some of the problems that a lot of people are experiencing with the controls. Otherwise, you're basically forced to find another human being to play with. Remote Play Together is your friend.

OK, let me first talk about what I love about this game - the "Insights". These are short little films mostly featuring interviews and stories from native Iñupiaq people. The majority of these are directly related to what's going on in the main story (itself an adaptation of an Iñupiaq tale) in some fashion. This gives a fairly bland puzzle-platformer a whole lot of depth. I ADORE this as a way to teach about culture.

Just one problem: the way to get these cinematics is to find owls scattered throughout the game. These are either so obvious as to be impossible to miss, or else kind of a pain in the butt to find without a lot of middle ground. Having to back-track through a pretty big chapter to grab one of these collectables doesn't feel good.

And I say that not because I have a particular disdain for backtracking for collectibles, but because 'Never Alone' itself isn't particularly fun to play. There's a bit of clunk to the movement that feels really unrefined. Things like the characters not wanting to turn as a jump is being executed resulting in the occasional awkward backwards hop when a direction and jump are pressed almost simultaneously, but the jump is registered first. These are the sorts of little things that wreck a game like this.

However the issue that frustrated me most (beyond the control scheme swapping thing I mentioned at the beginning) were some of the chase sequences at the end of the game. This game's mechanics are NOT built for reflexes. It's a co-op puzzle solving game and when it sticks to that it's OK. Not great, not even particularly challenging, but OK. But when it gets to the chases there are times where it feels like it wants the players to do things faster than it's allowing us to. Particularly in single player, it felt like running a race with weights on and was neither fun nor fair. While I did eventually succeed, it was largely in spite of a game that until that point seemed built to help me and not hinder me.

And this is why I can't [i]really[/i] recommend 'Never Alone'. It's a good experience for learning about a culture that most of us would otherwise barely know exists. But it's just not a very good [u]game[/u] and having to play it often feels more like it's getting in the way of the learning... which stinks because it's set up so well to have the two complement each other perfectly.

138365548.review: A delightfully informative adventure based on Iñupiat story and culture, Never Alone provides a short but exciting puzzle platformer starring a young girl Nuna and her guardian arctic fox. You trek through a never-ending blizzard to save your family from the devastating storm, traveling through several different regions of Alaska while encountering dangerous situations including the environment, wildlife, and a fire wielding man. You swap between Nuna and Fox to solve environmental puzzles in single player or control both simultaneously in local coop.  While short and relatively linear, it is fun to progress using different abilities corresponding to Fox and Nuna. The environments and atmosphere are gorgeous with beautiful scenery, moody atmospheric music, and large set pieces you parkour across. Despite being sidescrollers, the 3D backdrops help to expand the scope of the world around you. The game also does a great job  educating players about Iñupiat culture through optional educational videos that double as exploration collectables. These videos are very interesting, heartfelt and help reinforce the messages and themes present through the game. Although overall enjoyable, some mechanics such as the Bola and spirit manipulation are awkward to use quickly and effortlessly, leading to a lot of deaths when the game expects quick actions dependent on these mechanics. This might be easier to use in coop, which I have not tested personally. There was also some occasional collision and geometry issues when jumping or climbing but these were not game breaking or frequent. The optional Fox Tales DLC adds a few extra environments to explore with more challenging puzzles and more cultural insights videos. If you love games like Stray and can overlook a few rough edges, Never Alone is a very cool experience that can be casually enjoyed through in an evening. I would recommend buying on sale due to the overall short playtime and lack of replayability. I was recommended this game by my instructor for a Native American anthropology course and I’m very glad to have played it.

Are you tired of playing the same old games with no real substance? Do you want to learn something new while also having a blast? Look no further than Never Alone!

This game is like a cultural education on steroids, but with more fun and less homework. Here are several reasons why you need to play:

1. Experience the epic stories and rich culture of the Iñupiat people of Alaska, but with less history textbook and more epic adventure.
2. Enjoy stunning graphics that will make you forget you're not actually trekking through the frozen tundra, but with less frostbite and more cozy blanket.
3. Seamlessly weave together storytelling and gameplay, like a perfectly crafted pizza with all the toppings you love.
4. Control a young Iñupiaq girl and her arctic fox friend on an unforgettable journey, like a buddy comedy movie, but with less predictable plot twists and more cultural immersion.
5. Learn about different cultures and traditions in a fun and engaging way, like taking a virtual trip to Alaska, but with less airplane food and more video game snacks.

So, what are you waiting for? Grab your controller and get ready to embark on an unforgettable journey with Never Alone. You'll learn something new, have a ton of fun, and maybe even impress your friends with your newfound knowledge.

I would really like to give this a positive review, but I just can't do it. I love the setting of this game. I love how much real world culture is in the game. I love the optional live action cut-scenes where a lot of the lore is revealed. But...

As a game "Never Alone" is pretty annoying to play. The physics are jank as hell. The weather is hard to read and in numerous sections of the game the weather changes after each jump. The AI will often jump to it's death, which causes you to fail. The hitboxes are all over the place. The characters are easy to get stuck in the physics system; I accidentally got the main girls' character model stuck twice in a single play through. The game is very inconsistent.

"Never Alone" should have been a very relaxing adventure game. It has soft music and cute visuals. And for the most part it is a nice relaxing game, but that only makes the inevitable jank you experience that much more frustrating. You will run into sections of the game that will piss you off not because you are a bad gamer, but because the game is simply poorly implemented.

This game is better when played 2-player. If you have 2 players you won't be reliant on the poor AI not to kill itself and things will be generally faster since you don't have to swap characters to solve puzzles. However, playing as the fox is boring; the girl does the majority of the activities. So while it is better with 2-players it is also an imbalanced experience.

Lastly, the game is too simple and short. It is a pretty bare-bones 2D platformer that you will likely complete in less than 4 hours, and I don't have a strong urge to replay it personally. There are unfortunately just a lot of better games out there. It's not a bad game, but this is a genre with a ton of competition and "Never Alone" is at best another average game in the genre. If you are a die-hard fan of 2D adventure games then you will likely enjoy it, but if you are on the fence I would hold off on this one.

Si no quieres el texto, la conclusión está abajo del todo.


Never Alone es un videojuego de plataformas y puzles en scroll lateral con una historia ambientada en el folklore de los Iñupiat, un pueblo nativo de Alaska. 

La narración es sin duda lo más importante de Never Alone, pues nos enteramos del folklore de los Iñupiat tanto avanzando en la historia como obteniendo coleccionables que nos permitirán acceder a cinemáticas subtituladas y reales a modo de documental en la pantalla de inicio.


[b][u]• JUGABILIDAD[/u][/b]
Manejamos a Nuna y su compañero animal, un zorro, que deberán descubrir qué sucedió a su aldea a través de la ventisca.

Si jugamos solos, como es mi caso, podremos alternar entre Nuna y el zorro pulsando un botón para poder superar algunas pantallas, pero lo ideal es enredar a alguien y darle el Player2 para que sea tu zorro. Explico los motivos a continuación.


[u][b]• BUGS[/b][/u]
Efectivamente, claro, ¿cómo iba a salir un juego sin bugs?
- Si juegas solo, al manejar un personaje el juego está programado para que el otro te siga, pero no siempre sucede y las probabilidades de que se quede atascado son bastante elevadas.
- CUIDADO CON LAS PANTALLAS BAJO EL AGUA así, como concepto.
- Hay algunos fallos de que el segundo personaje se vaya donde quiere y no donde quieres que esté para resolver algún puzle, que no sucederían de haber otra persona a los mandos en lugar de ir una sola alternando.
- Muchas veces, cuando tienes que ir a puntos alejados de la pantalla, en lugar de "echarse la cámara para atrás" abarcando más zona, no lo hace. Te toca ir con uno de los dos personajes a ciegas.
- El juego crashea de repente.


[u][b]• APARTADO GRÁFICO[/b][/u]
Muy bonito, suave y cuidado. Las cinemáticas de la pantalla de inicio usualmente incluyen imágenes de los Iñupiat en blanco y negro y te da más sensación de estar viviendo parte de la leyenda de un pueblo.
Además, los efectos de acción y movimiento van acordes a lo que sucede y los sonidos de lástima o llanto cuando uno de los dos personajes muere, son conmovedores.


[u][b]• SOBRE EL DLC[/b][/u]
Añade una campaña nueva de la misma duración aproximadamente que el juego base. Transcurre en su mayoría bajo el agua o sobre una barca, con lo cual aumentan los bugs. Cuidadín.


[u][b]• CONCLUSIÓN[/b][/u]
Juego sencillo de plataformas en scroll lateral con algún puzle para avanzar de fase que no supone un desafío más allá de bugs, frustración si tienes que manejar a ambos personajes y crasheos. Muy asequible.
Es un "sí pero no", porque recomiendo jugar en cooperativo con otra persona y hacerlo con mando.

This game is a very cool project. The bite-sized documentary-style videos about the Inupiaq culture are very interesting, and they tie into the game well and always leave you waiting for the next one.
Does this game succeed as a game, though? I'd say well enough, but nothing extraordinary. The characters and the little fox are cute in the game's art style. The puzzles are more finicky than actually difficult. The weird thing with the story, though, is that it feels very... generic. It's a very specific story from a very specific real-life people, but honestly it's one that contains very common themes and a very common structure. It's the type of story you've already seen a hundred variations on, you've seen it embellished and appropriated and blended with other stories and other aesthetics and other emotions, but that's just it... this is one of those base stories that all those variations are based on. This game doesn't purport to be a novel take on a myth; it's simply a straightforward retelling of a traditional story. But the story doesn't *have* to be novel and captivating on its own. Placed within the context of the videos of real people telling their real experiences with the elements of the story, it works, it really works. And the fact that the game is narrated in the Inupiaq language is very cool too!

There is an unmatched importance to this title, and I have to go into this review with first saying I wholeheartedly believe everyone should play through Never Alone/Kisima Ingitchuna. It's been a long time since I played a game that felt IMPORTANT to play, let alone one that struck me emotionally within the first few minutes. 

It gives accurate representation to Alaska Natives, with dozens of natives being interviewed and adding input into every direction of the game. There's educational interviews in each chapter, though they are passionate, from the natives' personal lives, and so interesting! I fondly recall a story a woman told of her older brother having to raise polar bear cubs after he killed the mother in self defense, and how the woman would ride them "like horses"! lmao 

There's other gems in the interviews, like a man explaining how he can gauge how many inches down the ice levels are, and how they determine when ice will shift and it's time to move to a new area. Of course, mythological stories are also featured, and they're lovely. It was so cool to learn the true mythos origins of the Northern Lights, and that one I won't spoil---you have to hear it from the people themselves. 

Alaska Natives rarely get representation within American culture even, so I think purchasing this game and giving it a play, especially when it has coop (perfect game for playing through with a gf tbh), is so needed! It doesn't feature any violence at all either, and there's no combat--just escapes from close encounters with polar bears or mythos creatures. It would be a great educational buy for parents, that is still fully a game and charming. 

There is precision platforming in this, so if you're someone who enjoys walking simulators that tell a story, this won't be it. But I strongly encourage to try it anyway, the platforming and timing within the game makes sense. Alaska Natives deal with the harshest form of life, the worst predators, true and complete darkness, and even the ground below their feet is not trustworthy. This game features mechanics of shifting ground and blizzard winds that require precision, but it's used to tell the full story and I think was implemented well. 

The story itself is a popular mythological tale in their culture, and it is edited slightly to incorporate other cultural references and stories within it. The original story also featured a man, one of the interviews revealed, but they wanted to give the representation and platform to a woman----which is think is so endearing and beautiful in itself, that people who receive such little representation in general still wanted that representation to be of their women. <3 

I learned A LOT from this title, and after completing it, I rushed to tell my friends' some of the interview anecdotes I learned. It is a great game, I can't recommend it enough.

[Cons] My primary cons regard gameplay mechanics and it was immediately obvious that this game was gonna be a chore to play through because of them. 109228975.review:
I heard a lot about this game when it came out, and haven't gotten around to playing it until years later. I think, having completed it now, I see exactly why the game was so hot at the time, and why it hasn't been mentioned since.

What the game is doing is novel -- a video game adaptation of traditional Alaskan native folktales, and it really goes out of its way to let you know it's doing that. The narration is voiced by one of the storytellers (in his native tongue, no less), and the unlocks in the game are small clips that talk about their way of life and cultural traditions and beliefs. Art in the cutscenes is based on traditional scrimshaw, and zany mythological beasties and spirits abound.

Unfortunately, that's pretty much all of the substance the game is bringing. Nowadays, it smacks of woke culture by constantly and insistently rubbing in the player's face just how very much this narrative and setting are tradition...and I suppose the implication is that just because something is traditional, that is inherently meritorious?

I can't say I agree. The world is full of stories, and many are much more interesting than the one Never Alone tells, and many are much better told and better explored.

The gameplay just isn't very good. The puzzles aren't any more in-depth or engaging than solving the problem of how to move to the next platform ad nauseum. The AI companion several times jumped straight to their death, forcing a restart on me, and several other times, moved or disappeared the platform I was jumping from/to, making me jump to [i]my[/i] death. Inputs feel floaty and droppy, ledge grabs are inconsistent yet required nearly everywhere, and good input design, like coyote time, buffered inputs, or even being able to gracefully change facing are all extremely noticeably absent. 

Which is a shame, because the broad strokes of a great game are in here. Delving into interesting lore and mythos of other cultures is incredibly engaging, and the potential of a co-op platformer has been proven again and again. If you want a game which tells a great story and has that kind of gameplay, play Brothers - A tale of Two Sons, which came out a year before Never Alone, and is superior in every way.

Never Alone is an attempt at mixing media to tell a northern tale and teach the player a thing or two about the inuit culture.
You'll alternate between 2D animated cinematics, platformer gameplay and optional didactic filmed interviews telling you some facts about the inuit way of life and beliefs. The whole thing has been created in collaboration with people grew up in this culture.
I'm taking some time to explain all of this because, in my opinion, such an attempt is already an ambitious undertaking worth looking into. But does it succeeds at its attempts?
If you see this game as a way of learning something, yes, definitely. It showcases inuit art, language, a tale, and information. Some of this content may feel like spoon feeding, so it was a good call to make some of it optional.
The animation is nice, both in game and in the cinematics. The art direction in general is very coherent and nicely executed. I especially enjoyed the lighting effects on the ice and snow. The gameplay on the other hand is okay but could have done with a little more polish to make it more enjoyable. Some phases were somewhat unclear or frustrating to play, and I did run into the occasional collision bug. I sadly didn't play with someone, so maybe it makes the experience harder. It doesn't make it bad, and I managed to finish the story in 3,5 hours + watch all the interviews I unlocked.
The two main characters are endearing, even without a line of dialogue. The story is nice and has some good surprises.

So all in all, Never Alone isn't a great platformer, but that's not what you play it for. I recommend it especially if you're curious about experimental ways of telling a story, and / or the inuit culture.

95224164.review:
Never Alone is a retelling of the Iñupiat story, Kunuuksaayuka, with the titular character swapped out for a girl and a fox to highlight the role of nature and its spirits in Iñupiat life. Their home on the Alaskan coast is beautifully rendered in brilliant whites and gentle blues and the Iñupiat relationship with this environment, as a living creature both offering aid and promising danger, is blended perfectly with mechanics of a platformer.

The platforming itself, and the partner-based puzzle solving that comes with it, is wisely not difficult enough to get in the way of that story. But even if it was interested in providing a challenge, there's no real consequence for failure... unless you're susceptible to emotional manipulation. In that case, watching the friends morn each other will add a little bit of tension to the experience. Though the somewhat clumsy controls are just as likely to break that tension for you. 

While I wouldn't call the gameplay a distraction for the aforementioned reasons, it's not the main driving force of Never Alone either. All the obstacles and challenges, how ever meager they are, are just there to provide a hook for the story being told piece by piece in the Iñupiat language. That story provides a hook itself for the Cultural Insight videos unlocked throughout the game. This is exactly the kind of educational material I wish I had growing up. By turning these small lectures into prizes you've earned, it builds its own sense of engagement instead of simply demanding your attention. And for that reason, I think these sorts of games are better at teaching than any documentary or lesson plan ever could be.

93143129.review:
This is a tough game to review because it fits into so many categories.

On one level, it's a 2-D platformer. To get from each area to the next, you need to maneuver the girl and the fox to jump across gaps, climb cliffs, and avoid dangers. The girl can shoot ice with her bolo to break it, while the fox can summon tribal spirits to help get through the area. One player can switch which character to control (like the LEGO games), or two players can control both at the same time. I wouldn't say it's a particularly noteworthy platformer, though. There are no lives or items and there's no backtracking; you've just got to figure out the puzzle of how to get through the area, and you've got to have enough manual dexterity to maneuver two characters through it (unless you're playing with a friend).

On another level, it's a story. read aloud in a native Alaskan tongue while subtitles appear on-screen. I enjoyed being exposed to the language, and the spirits summoned by the fox were fascinatingly weird-looking with their tribal designs (especially the Aurora Borealis, which here becomes a wonderfully-designed obstacle). But the story itself was a typical tribal kind of story, just a sequence of strange events happening. There's no plot to it, no character development.

And on a third level, it's an educational tool. Playing through the game unlocks documentary videos about the tribe and its heritage which can be played at any point. These have a good production value, but I only watched two of them until I got bored and wanted to return to the game.

The game's title, "Never Alone," isn't really relevant to the game. My best guess is that it means the girl is never alone even when she's separated from her people because the fox is always with her - but there's nothing in the story that's nearly this introspective. Also, I completed the game in two and a half hours (even after multiple tries on some areas), so $14.99 might not be a worthwhile price for such a short game.

There could have been some slight replayability to this game, because it keeps track of how many "cultural insights" (unlockable videos) you find in each area. Unfortunately, these are hidden achievements, so that even if you [i]know[/i] it's keeping track of these, there's no way to see how many you've found until you've found them all.

If you enjoy a puzzle platformer with a story being read to you in an unusual language while you unlock documentary videos, then this game is just your thing. For me, though, it fit into many categories but none of them well.

89728046.review:
Never Alone is a 2d platformer.

You play as a young Alaskan Inuit girl and her white fox (you can switch between them in-level). You're on a quest to stop the storm that's threatening your village. On your way, you deal with everything that the harsh conditions of the Arctic Tundra have to offer. Your progression is accompanied by a documentary film interviewing real natives, addressing themes you come across, such as traditions, hunting and even global warming. Experiencing everything, including that short DLC, will get you almost 5 hours in playtime.

Mechanically, the game is very raw and clunky, lacking in level design (which is pretty generic and uninspired in many sections) and polish. The girl character can shoot a bola, run, jump, swim, row a bot and carry/throw items. The fox can run, jump, swim and interact with spirits in the game world that act as dynamic movable platforms. While controlling one, the other character follows (also performing jumps and climbing). Platforming is mostly not demanding, but there are some Limbo-esque precise platforming sequences that can annoy you, mainly due to the game not communicating what will kill you in a clear manner. The wind element is probably the only interesting gameplay feature, as it pushes you around.

Art style is cute for a few minutes, but nothing to write home about. There's a Inuit narrator talking some jibrish here and there and not adding much to the experience.

Overall, I wanted to like this one, but it just didn't click for me. I do not recommend it, unless it costs up to $1 or in a giveaway.

Never Alone isn’t really much of a game, at least not in the sense of what I would generally consider a game. That’s not to say it’s bad; far from it, actually! Never Alone is more of an interactive story and documentary than a game, but the combination was certainly refreshing, and quite honestly a pleasure.

In Never Alone, you start off with a couple of documentary and interview style videos (insights), introducing you to the premise of the game. You then take on the role of a young girl and her arctic fox companion as you venture out into the land to find the source of all the blizzards in her village. You can play with a friend in co-op but, naturally, I played solo. Along the way, you unlock more insights, providing the background behind something you’ve just experienced or you’re about to experience. These are accounts taken from actual Inupiaq and reflect their experiences, allowing the game to portray certain aspects of their lives, beliefs, and stories.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2435674369

The gameplay is simple. It’s a side-scroller with some basic platforming and puzzle elements, but quite frankly, I don’t think it needed to be anything more than that. I wasn’t expecting an action packed FPS anyway, and the experience was a rather educational and insightful one, and done in a way that kept me engaged throughout. If you’re one of the people who skips videos and dialogue in a game then you’ll likely be disappointed with the gameplay, so don’t skip them; play the game for what it is, embracing all of its content.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2435674572

The Foxtales DLC adds a separate little story with the same characters, lasting somewhere around 50 minutes. It’s not quite as charming as the base game, but the puzzle elements require slightly more thought (not drastically more). It’s certainly worth experiencing if you enjoy the main game.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2435675308

I’d say Never Alone is perfect for all ages, and a great way to relax and learn something new about a different region and people; one that I knew very little about to begin with. I actually made the “mistake” of starting the game at around 23:30, thinking I’d play for half an hour or so and finish up the following day. Of course, I didn’t want to stop once I started and ended up finishing the game in one sitting, somewhere between two and a half and three hours later. No regerts! Of course, for any achievement hunters out there, these ones are quick and easy to get, although the last four do require the Foxtales DLC.

Never Alone (Kisima Ingitchuna) is a cute and beautiful puzzle platformer game; okay let’s talk about the story.

It was just another day for the young Iñupiat girl named Nuna, but as she was taking home food for her Village a mysterious blizzard had come. 

But unlike other blizzards this one would not cease, with the threat of starvation looming over her people the young girl sets out on a journey to find the source of the eternal blizzard. But she is not alone for a young fox comes with her to lend a paw. But can these two unlikely heroes do it? In a land that with one wrong move could be your death.

Now the likes. The art/graphics style is very beautiful it's just nice to just stop and look at it sometimes. The levels are good and pretty varied from Snowy Tundras, to abandoned villages to even forests.

The game’s story is very good as it’s told like a fairytale. The atmosphere in the game is very good it can be beautiful and kind of spooky sometimes. The puzzles were Fair and weren't that hard to figure out. The soundtrack/music was very nice especially the part with the owl man music.

The two best parts were one those cutscenes that were like a scrimshaw art, they were simple yet beautiful very interesting looking. Two those cultural insights were very good it was cool to learn about the Iñupiat culture, way of life and their beliefs.

Now the dislikes. Well there is this big bug in the game; you see the game can be played with a controller. But every time I played with a controller and switched to the fox or the girl the controller would lock up and go into co-op mode and no matter what I did like unplugging the control and plug it back in or switching it back to single player mode, every time I touched that controller it would always go back to co-op mode. 

It was just really frustrating I tried the fix that was in the discussions and it still did not work, but you can still play the game with a keyboard and mouse.

The game can be a little awkward to control if you're using the keyboard and mouse instead of a controller. Game can also be a bit short you can probably beat it in 3 hours if you're not going after achievements. Game is also bit expensive for such a short game but not too bad. 

Okay with that said Never Alone (Kisima Ingitchuna) is a cute and beautiful puzzle platformer game, with a very good story, very beautiful art/graphics style and very good insights into the Iñupiat culture. 

So if you want to play an interesting platformer and you want to learn about a different culture then this game could be for you.

I enjoyed the game's story, its informative video insights/lectures, its tie to Alaskan Inuit folklore, and the adorable little fox companion. The animation is beautiful and well done; it kind of reminds me of the old claymation shorts. The creature designs are also very imaginative and well drawn.

However, I found the controls frustrating at times, especially during chase sequences and the sequence where you ride a tree across a frozen lake. The camera close-ups often don't let you see what obstacles are coming up until they're right on top of you, hints come late, and I often found it difficult to mentally switch between the characters (remembering when to switch, remembering what their controls were, etc.) which got me killed numerous times as I tried to manage through the chases. Further, sometimes the other character will freeze in place while I try to move on, and other times they will try to catch up to the played character and get themselves killed. 

In addition, the fox character became difficult to manage later in the game, as his movements felt like swimming mechanics (hard to manoeuvre at the best of times, worse when trying to complete timed events), and his range for manipulating spirits was often not big enough.

Finally, the instructions for explaining the control keys were often difficult to read due to the font, and the close grouping of the movement keys (A,S,W,D) and "Switch Characters" keys (Q and F) on the keyboard often meant that I was accidentally switching characters while trying to run away. 

Overall, if you love learning about different cultural beliefs and have the patience for the control issues that I have mentioned, I do recommend playing this game. It is very sweet.

[h1]Una historia que merecía ser contada[/h1]

No es muy habitual ver juegos parecidos Never Alone, si es que existen, y no es por el hecho de ser un plataformas, obviamente, sino por el tema que trata y por cómo lo hace.

Creo que la mejor manera de definirlo, sería decir que estamos ante un juego-documental, uno que trata sobre los Iñupiaq, es decir, y para situarnos mejor, los esquimales de Alaska.

El juego nos cuenta la historia de una chica y un zorro ártico, pero quedarnos ahí sería no haber aprendido nada de la experiencia que este juego intenta transmitir, y es la razón por la que merece tanto la pena.

La historia que se nos cuenta es una basada en los cuentos ancestrales que se cuentan oralmente entre los Iñupiaq de generación en generación, y a través de los cuales se intentan trasmitir diferentes valores o experiencias mismas de la vida en el ártico.

De todos modos, el juego no nos plantea la historia y ya nosotros sacamos las conclusiones, ni mucho menos. Durante la aventura encontraremos en determinados niveles diferentes búhos que desbloquearán un vídeo determinado contándonos diferentes aspectos de la cultura Iñupiaq, ya sea su relación con la naturaleza, sus creencias, o historias personales de diferentes personas, entre otras, y todo con el objetivo de acercar a la gente este pueblo y su mensaje sobre su comprensión del mundo y la naturaleza.

Esto es realmente interesante, y te hace descubrir una manera diferente de comprender las cosas y, además, ver cómo han vivido y viven esas personas en ese ambiente tan sumamente hostil.

Por supuesto, el juego no va de ver vídeos, obviamente, pero es un excelente añadido que hace que toda la experiencia gane muchos enteros en su conjunto.

Como tal, nuestro objetivo es viajar con la pequeña esquimal atravesando toda clase de peligros y entornos peligrosos para averiguar qué le ha sucedido a nuestro pueblo y por qué han desparecido todos.

Durante la aventura, al principio de la misma más concretamente, nos encontraremos con un zorro ártico, el cual nos ayudará utilizando sus habilidades para poder seguir avanzando.

El juego puede jugarse tanto solo como con alguien, tomando una persona el control de la niña y la otra el control del zorro. Sin embargo, no hay ningún problema si decidimos jugar solos, ya que tanto el zorro como la niña responden perfectamente por sí solos.

Obviamente, si nos ponemos a hacer idioteces por el entorno, es muy probable que volvamos un poco loca a la IA y el personaje no nos siga tal y como nos gustaría, pero eso no suele pasar si uno juga como una persona normal. Además, siempre podremos, y tendremos, que cambiar entre los diferentes personajes para realizar una acción u otra.

En lo que se refiere al nivel de calidad del plataformeo, yo diría que cumple sobradamente, al menos con mando que es como lo jugué yo. Ni es muy fácil, ni es injusto. Simplemente te exige un mínimo razonable para seguir avanzando. Eso no quiere decir que vaya a ser un paseo, eso seguro, ya que moriremos en más de una ocasión, y de dos, a lo largo de nuestra aventura.

En lo tocante a su calidad gráfica, el juego cumple igualmente con soltura. Los entornos están muy bien recreados, así como las animaciones de los diferentes personajes que pueblen los diferentes escenarios, especialmente los de la niña, los cuales están a un gran nivel.

Los escenarios son bastante variados, sobre todo si tenemos en cuenta que estamos en el ártico, en entornos nevados donde la imaginación no puede desmadrarse demasiado, pero, aun así, habrá bastantes momentos de sorpresa durante la aventura.

En lo referente a la calidad sonora, el juego ofrece unos efectos de sonido y de voces bastante buenos, además de utilizar el idioma Iñupiaq, haciendo que todo gane mucha mayor verosimilitud.

La duración del juego es bastante escasa por otro lado, durando unas 4 horas, y si te haces con el DLC, algo que recomiendo, se irá a las 5 en total. El DLC cuenta una historia diferente, con otro mensaje diferente y más vídeos explicativos acerca de esa historia y del porqué de la misma.

En definitiva, Nerver Alone es una experiencia realmente sorprendente, donde se une una buena experiencia plataformera con una intención genuina de dar a conocer una cultura bastante desconocida más allá de los tópicos de sobra conocidos. Sin duda, es un título bastante diferente a lo habitual, y tal vez por eso sea aún más recomendable.

Based off of Iñupiat narratives that have been passed down through the generations, Never Alone follows the story of Kunuuksaayuka. Upper one games have preserved this story in  a different form to its oral roots - allowing a person to experience the story through a different medium and watch it unfold before their eyes.

It is said that a boy and his parent lived alone without any knowledge of anyone nearby. The son, whose name was Kunuuksaayuka, was old enough to hunt and had grown capable of doing many things. They were not in need of food. The son was able to hunt and there were many caribou. Thus was the life of the woman and her son. One winter day, as they lived in their usual manner, eating caribou as before, there came a blizzard. The weather did not clear up as one blizzard was followed by yet another blizzard. It is said that with each gust of wind, the powdery snow blew in every direction. Following that, it stopped briefly and then became windy all over again. It was difficult to see anything in the blizzard. The woman’s son was unable to hunt caribou. They began to run out of food. Although Kunuuksaayuka was a good hunter during clear weather, the blizzardy weather simply was not a time to hunt. It was dangerous to travel at any distance. Overall: 7/10

Short Review: Never Alone and Never Alone Foxtales are puzzle platformers with beautiful stories based on Inuit Culture and folklore. The visual representation of the stories and the accompanying music are amazing. However, the gameplay is quite frustrating.

Long Review: The Never Alone games do very well to pay homage to the Inuit culture through story-telling as well as the unlockable "cultural insight" documentary clips about where the mythology that the games are based on. It gives you insight on the culture straight from folks belonging to that culture. You also get insights on how climate change is affecting them. While playing the game and absorbing the artwork, the narration and the story, one cannot help but fall in love with the culture. Watching the folks in the documentary clips recount fun as well as thrilling stories from their lives brought a smile to my face.

I played Never Alone and Foxtales in "single player" game mode and it was pretty clear the game was designed to be enjoyed with a friend. The game reminded me of Disney's Pocahontas platformer game in that you often have to switch between the girl (Nuna) and the Fox to solve puzzles. 
However, whereas the animal companion in Pocahontas had his own path most of the time to get you to the end, in Never Alone, you find yourself solving the platforming puzzles and traps twice: once for Nuna and once for the fox. If you control one character and leave the AI to follow you as the other, it will most definitely fall into the trap. Additionally, at the harder platforming traps, if you don't constantly switch between characters to make sure they are close to each other, the character whom you have already taken beyond the trap will try to back-track and come back to the other character when you switch.
Other timed levels require very quick switching between characters to remove obstacles and those end up being very frustrating.
The controls are also quite laggy for some reason, so puzzles that require quick responses can be infuriating.

Bugs: 
1) The worst bug I encountered was one where if you die and restart from the previous checkpoint, the character often spawns in places where you are immediately killed.
2) One of the boss levels bugs out once you die so it's hard to tell what you are supposed to do.
3) The "Cultural Insight" videos often close immediately when opened. You have to try to open them several times for them to play.

Despite the frustrations, I would still recommend you get the game and play with a friend.

68637424.review:
There are two things to distinguish here: the cultural significance of this game and the game itself. From a societal and cultural perspective, this is a great documentary piece with seamless integration of a fable and game. The Cultural Insights and interviews are interesting and worth watching, absolutely. There's only positive to say here.

Now, on to the gameplay.

The positive:

Story: It works well and is interesting, tying the game to reality seamlessly. The little owls you find along the way fill the gaps into the more culturally-significant aspects of it.

Visuals: Pleasing and pleasant, and overall fitting.

Sound design: Works well, no complaints.

Characters: Thought-out and surprising, in some ways.

Forgiving: The game's forgiving and wants you to progress, with checkpoints being abundant.

Overall, it works really well to convey culture through game format. If you can watch the documentary, do so, on another platform if you'd rather not play a game.

Needs improvement:

Level design, late-game: The last few levels are frustrating because of platforming that's imprecise and kind of clunky. There are portions where you must be spot-on, but the fluid controls don't really lend themselves well to that kind of accuracy.

The Bola: Aiming with the joystick's weird. Try it with the keyboard, then go to a controller. I get what they were going for, you're pulling back and letting it go, but... yeah. The aiming's weird, too.

Late-game fox character: No spoilers here, the Fox is slow and kind of odd to maneuver late-game.

Nice piece of cultural significance with odd platforming sometimes. Casual, interesting, and worthwhile if you can give it some patience from the gameplay side.

100% positive review for the cultural insights and story sequences.  Thank you to the Alaskan Iñupiaq community for the opportunity to listen to your experiences!   The format is informal, personal and entertaining, with lots of individual stories and perspectives.     

The animated story sequences throughout the game are done in a nice style that evokes the legends well.  The overall idea of working with others to survive and not being self centred tie the insights, story and game together.

As for the game itself, mixed review.  The visuals are quite attractive, if bleak at times.  I really liked the design of the helper spirits, otherworldly yet comforting.  The characters of Nuna and the Fox are both very cute, making it kind of sad when they fall off a ledge, unfortunately (Especially since the surviving character will begin crying for a few seconds before the sequence restarts.).  The puzzle platformer element is sometimes fun, other times a bit tedious and sometimes just frustrating.  I did encounter a bug where a boss fight that should have been easy became impossible.  When I redid the sequence, including the chase that led up to the fight, which I really didn't want to re-do, the fight was over in a few tries.  To be fair I don't really like platformers anymore except metroidvanias, but this one did seem quite clunky.  The controls don't matter so much in the first half of the game as not much precision is required.  In the second half the difficulty is increased but the controls still aren't responsive enough to allow you to make precise moves.  As others have mentioned, the AI controlling the second character in 1 player mode will sometimes jump the second character off a ledge, forcing you to redo a sequence.  So it's hard to recommend the game itself without caveat.  I mainly bought this for the cultural elements, which are totally worth it.  Just don't expect the fun platforming experience of the year.

I liked this game. I do think that it made a big difference that I came in with specific expectations from having read about it. It met them. Those expectations were:
[list]
[*]an engagement with the cultural traditions of the Iñupiat first and foremost, emphatically including the embedded videos and narrative frame of a storyteller in that tradition telling you the story. If you are not here for those things, you may be in the wrong place.
[*]elegant visuals. Not just in the gameplay, but in the [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scrimshaw]scrimshaw[/url]-style artwork of the cutscenes that tell elements of the story.
[*]simple mechanics. Yes, we found the game simple. It's linear; the challenges are straightforward. It's not indifferently or carelessly made; it's more like a game that is a framework for the primary objectives noted above.
[*]nice co-op. It was enjoyable to play with friends; it was enjoyable to do the puzzles with friends, and to experience the game's educational aspects. That was deliberately how we approached it, and the approach was rewarded.

If I'd had different expectations--if I'd just hopped into this game as a solo player, looking for a platformer--I think I would have needed to quickly adjust my hopes or just not have as good a time. But going in [i]with[/i] those specific expectations, me and a group of friends had a really nice time. We beat it in a relaxed evening together; it's a lovely experience.

Hi and welcome to my epic review of this epic video game. I will list the goods, the bads, and that's it. WOo. Also to preface, I had to play this game as homework for my Game Design study, which is why I played all of it.


 [h1] What the fuck is it about [/h1]
Never alone is a game about a little girl who wants to find out what's causing the blizzard that's pestering the home town. On her journey she almost fuckin dies so a fox has to save her. From that point on they decide to work together for some reason. 

[h2] The main gameplay [/h2]
Never Alone focuses on the little girl and the fox how they work together. In multiplayer, one player controls the fox and one player controls the little girl, they both have different abilities so they can't continue without each other. You can also just play in single player, then you switch between the two characters with the press of a button. The girl and the fox have to overcome puzzles and platforming like this.

[h3] So what's good? [/h3]

Never alone mainly focuses on a country's very specific culture. It does this by making the entire story of the game based on one of the folk tales of that country. It does this very charmingly, accompanied by cutscenes with interesting visuals I was pretty interested.

Besides that, the visuals looked absolutely stunning. I can tell they put most of the budget of this game into the visuals, but I'll get to that later. 

You really do get immersed by the sound design and the visuals, when there's a snow storm you almost feel cold, and never did I have the feeling of something looking out of place or just straight up bad.

[h4] Um so what's bad [/h4]
Basically the rest. Honestly, let me go into detail because I have many fucking gripes with this game.

First off, I started it off and my dual shock 4 controller did not want to work with the game itself. I tried a lot of things, but the game just refused to acknowledge my controller. I works fine for literally any other game in my steam library. This forced me to play this platforming game with mouse and keyboard, which already was a bad sign.

Then the gameplay began, and it started off charmingly and nice. But as it got more difficult, it got less and less fun. It's a platformer, but the controls are [b] atrocious [/b]. Legit, I got so frustrated with this game, I just wanted to be done with it at some point. This frustration basically ruinted all the other good aspects of the game for me. Due to it I wanted to skip cutscenes, and dying due to the controls being extremely inconsistent and unresponsive really was not fun at ALL.

Besides this, the game is buggy as well. For instance, if you're playing in  single player, the character you're not controlling will follow you controlled by an AI. This is nice because you don't have to keep switching, this is not nice because they will sometimes just fucking yeet themselves into a pit, causing the section to start over (yes this actually happened). 

Besides that bugginess, the environment was clunky as hell. My character fell in place at least 13 times during my playthrough, it was laughable honestly. 

[h5] In conclusion, would I recommend it? [/h5]

Never alone lacks in every single thing that makes it a game, the visuals are the only redeeming quality, and in my opinion it's better off being a movie. I would not recommend this game to anyone, due to it not being fun in the slightest. You will likely not have a good time with it.

Thank you for reading!

"We were not into an '8 to 5' kind of time.  We're in a totally different kind of time; we're in 'ecological time.'"  Ronald Aniqsuaq

This is a gentle gameplay experience, with optional documentary explaining daily human life in the arctic, which is interwoven from the many local species.

The bottom of the visible food chain in a frozen environment is going to be fish - not grass or other plants.  Hence human life is almost exclusively maintained by hunting.  I don't expect any discussion of vegetarianism in this game, as plants practically don't exist (at least I haven't seen any within the first hour of the game).  Rather, this is a discussion of life begetting life, and at an intuitive level the mind guiding each individual to survive.  There is folklore and animism explaining how the frozen world works and remains whole.

In the gameplay, you are the little girl who is accompanied by an arctic fox to find her village after getting lost in a blizzard.  You can play with the keyboard or with a gamepad controller.  Switch between the fox and the girl to access special moves.  It is a long series of platforming puzzles to go through - there's some exploring, and the solutions to the puzzles are sometimes off-screen in the surrounding area.  

The Game In A Nutshell:
The artwork is very immersive, presenting animated drawings of the girl's story, and the filmaking is 5-star documentary quality.  The game is essentially something like a History Channel documentary explaining the daily life of arctic indigenous people broken up over time by a fairly easy puzzle platformer game.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1880706431

I like to play this in small doses, and learn about this remote people who live in a very hard place, smiles beaming, happy to be here.

The folktale was fun, the fox companion made adorable barking noises, the story was dire enough to be significant - but the gameplay was absolutely atrocious. Many other reviews mention how the frustratingly buggy AI of the non-player character - girl or fox - is combatted with a second player, thus playing into the themes of teamwork and togetherness present in the game, but that still wouldn't save the floaty controls, poor collision detection, and extremely linear, uninspired level design that makes playing Never Alone a nightmare. I also question the inclusion of the documentary clips - wouldn't it be far more innovative and fun to weave the cultural education into the gameplay itself through bonus items or optional areas? Lots of games with fictional cultures and histories do a good job of showing aspects of that world through bits and pieces the player experiences and picks up, so why not apply that to a real culture and in doing so increase the player's sense of discovery and enjoyment without feeling like their video game came with a side of PBS? It's a shame, because a game with a unique storyline, concept, and worthy goal of educating players about a culture they're likely unfamiliar with could definitely have been great - but its good qualities can't support it through the dull and frustrating game design.

I was quite skeptical of playing this game as it typically isn’t the type of game I play but with that being said I actually really enjoyed it. It was a lot of fun. 

[h1]Game[/h1]
Never Alone is a puzzle-platformer that is developed and published by E-Line Media and Upper One Games. The game is based on a myth which is being narrated to you as you play. It starts off by showing you how Nuna is separated from her village during a really devastating blizzard when she is then mysteriously saved by a magical snowy, white fox. You both decide to become friends and team up to find out what is the cause of the blizzard and put a stop to it by any means necessary. 

The gameplay is very simple and straightforward. You are either constantly running from a threat or you are solving puzzles, as you need to if you are wanting to make progress with the game. The puzzles were easy to solve but in order to make it less boring they’ve added an option to swap between the character. However, they do have their own abilities and some puzzles can only be solved as that certain character. It’s actually quite neat that they have included this as it makes the person playing think more and put more effort into solving the puzzles. It’s far better than letting the AI doing it for you. Also, the game is very sort. I managed to complete both the main story and the Foxtales DLC in 4-5 hours. So, it’s definitely a game you would be able to complete in one sitting. 

[h1]Things I like about the game: [/h1]
•	The controls were simple and easy to use. I’ve seen people complaining about it, but in my time playing I haven’t had any trouble. 
•	The overall art of the game is just amazing.
•	It was short. Some people may see this as a con, but I can’t really see it being enjoyed as much if it was a long story. I feel like it would just be really repetitive and boring. So, I’m glad it is a short game.
•	The puzzles were easy to solve so anyone would be able to pick up the game and solve it. It’s not like you had to think a lot about it when solving or it had multiple puzzles in one. 
•	Not only is it an awesome story driven game, it is also very educational as you get to learn about their culture. 
•	When the characters were first introduced I instantly liked them. Even more so when I made further progress. I just loved the bond between these two characters.   

[h1]Things that could improve: [/h1]
•	The puzzles were easy to solve but I would of liked to see a variety of puzzles as repeating the same ones was very boring and repetitive. So, it would have been nice to solve different ones. 
•	I would have liked to see more interactions between the characters as well as exploring their personalities further. 

[h1]Graphics & Sound [/h1]
The graphics was really good despite being in a deserted setting. I thought both of the characters was very well designed and animated. From all the small details that is added, it does clearly show how much the developers care about this game. For instance, seeing the hood getting blown of Nuna’s head from the impact of the wind, the movement of the characters when swimming underwater. The scenery was all the same, it was all taking place in one location, but I fair enjoyed it. 

I enjoyed the sound as well as, I enjoy the little narration between the chapters that’s explaining the story. I also enjoyed the sound of the wind howling, along with whenever the characters were moving, hearing their footsteps. I thought the music was good as well, it fits in well with the whole atmosphere. 

[h1]Did I Experience Any Bugs? [/h1]
During my time playing I didn’t experience any bugs. This is including the main story as well as the Foxtales DLC

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Would I recommend this game? Yes, I would but not for its price. Don’t get me wrong it is a very good 2d puzzle-platformer with a good story. That is also very educational as you get to learn about their culture but for the playtime you are getting with this game along with the DLC I would rather just wait for it going on sale. Unless money isn’t that big of an issue, if that’s the case, sure go for it. If you do end up getting it, I hope you enjoy this fabulous experience.

I got this game over a year ago and for some reason I didn't do a review on it back then even though I really enjoyed it. Thus, for #LoveIndies I went back to it briefly to yet again spark up those feelers of playing it the first time and here are my thoughts on it.

+++ Folklore and it's presentation
++ Animations
++ Animated tribal art
++ Cultural Insights
+ Puzzle mechanics
+ Cute Art

In Never Alone you play through folklore of the Iñupiat, one of the native tribes of Alaska, narrated by the elders of the tribe passing on stories as they were passed on to them. These stories are beautiful and harsh, as is the environment where those stories originate and they take you on an adventure to understand the values and hardships of the Iñupiat.
You play as a Iñupiat girl, Nuna and her furry friend, both having their own little tricks up their sleeves. You solve puzzles, escape tight situations and converse with spirits by switching between those two playable characters. (There's also a co-op mode where you can play with your friend, each controlling one character.)
The game art is quite nice, especially considering it's on Unity and first released in 2014. The animations are definitely cute, but what really sold the game to me visually was the animated tribal art as story cinematics. The native spoken narration by the elderly made the gameplay very immersive and made it feel like I was but a child sitting by the fireplace and listening to my elders telling stories of their youth.
The only thing that bothered me, which unfortunately is a rather big thing when it comes to gameplay, was the wacky control mechanics. It felt like there was definitely some thoughts put behind them, but the execution was rather clunky and made the gameplay just that much less fluid and enjoyable. I recommend playing with a controller instead of a keyboard and mouse.

Overall, I enjoyed the game a lot. I felt sad after finishing the initial story but was rewarded with a DLC, that made everything better. I love to learn about folklore of other cultures and Never Alone definitely pulled through both as a game and as an educative experience.
P.s. Yeah, I cried.

[h1]Culturally charming action platformer with terri-bad controls.[/h1]

[h1]GAMEPLAY:[/h1]
Never Alone is an imaginative buddy, action-platformer. You swap control between two different characters, Nuna and Fox, on a quest to find out what's causing a perpetual blizzard. The storyline (apparently) is based on actual Inuit mythology. 

[h1]PROS:[/h1]
[list]
[*][b][u]Cultural Narrative[/u][/b]: I won't spoil the story here nor will I be applying my cultural opinions to a work based on another culture's mythology, but I can say that it was very refreshing to play a game from an untapped cultural mythos. The characters and storytelling were definitely new and unique to my eyes. 

[*][b][u]Art & Sound [/u][/b]:While not the sharpest graphics I've ever seen, the artstyle was charming and pleasant. The set pieces were fairly clear providing information to the player and the character designs were interestingly diverse. I also thought the background music was wonderfully atmospheric. 

[*][b][u]Puzzle Design[/u][/b]: I noted that some of the puzzles made particuluarly clever use of the few abilities and game mechanics. 

[*][b][u]Storytelling[/u][/b]: I also really apreciated how some of the more dramatic moments in the story synched up with the sound and the setting in such a way to create a sort of flow, which would have made for an exceptionally exciting experience... if not for some of the game's flaws. 
[/list]
[h1]CONS:[/h1]
[list]
[*][b][u]General Glitchiness[/u][/b]: This game is fraught with performance issues. At least once every play session a screen would appear during gameplay informing me that there were performance issues and that lowering my resolution settings would help. This occured at all resolutions. Changing resolutions never helped avoid this warning, nor improved performance. 

For the record, I have a machine running a CORE i7 6500U, 12GB of RAM and a Geforce 930M. I can play Assassin's Creed without a problem on this machine, so I doubt cartoon graphics were creating the issue. 

[*][b][u]Lack of Editing?[/u][/b]: The cutscenes telling the story randomly change the protagonist's gender from female to male towards the end of the story. Intentional? Or Inconsistent? How am I to judge?

[*][b][u]CO-OP AI liked to Troll[/u][/b]: There were many occasions when my ally (whomever I wasn't playing at the time) would gleeflully run into a monster or jump to it's death, through no fault of my own. Good ally AI is a must for any buddy-platformer games. Just sayin'.

[*][b][u]HORRENDOUS Controls[/u][/b]: There was about a half a second delay in response time during play at irregular, but persistent intervals. Hit boxes were sketchy, maneuvering spirits was exceptionally clunky- sometimes moving too fast and other times moving painfully slow, without rhyme or reason... [b]AND F*^%$ THOSE BOLAS CONTROLS![/b]

Taken together, it made what would be an otherwise pleasant and uplifting game into an incredibly and needlessly frustrating slog. 
[/list]

[h1]CONCLUSION: [/h1]
I am a staunch advocate for games being a form of artistic expression and that video games are at their best when they feature mechanics that are fun to play and when they tell a story that's engaging. The fact that a little indie company was established that shares this view is admirable and it makes me want games like Never Alone to succeed. 

That said, I cannot help but express the opinion that the technical execution of this game, particularly the controls, are [b][u]unequivocally[/u][/b] bad and the game overall lacks polish. 

Ironically then, Never Alone is a game that is the complete opposite of your typical EA gaming franchise- focused heavily on story and narrative while mostly negligent with regard to gameplay. Womp Womp. >_<

49796325.review:
I have only played the main game and not the dlc bonus story upon writing this review.  That said, there's a good chance I'll get the dlc in the future.

Never Alone is a 2d platformer game where you play as both a girl lost in the snowy lands and an arctic fox that helps her.  There as an ability in this game to co-op, where one player can play the girl and one play the fox.  I decided to play this game solo, where you hit a button to switch between the girl and fox - to verify that yes, it can be done seamlessly.  

The game length is short, and made longer by interspersing videos about life in that region and the various traditions of the people.  These videos are very interesting and insightful, and brought an extra amount of depth to the adventure that you just wouldn't get by playing without them.  It also made the game feel a bit like a cultural history lesson.  Additionally, the videos felt like part of the game play instead of being an interruption, and I had fun collecting them all.  

The animation is beautiful, and the cutscenes in between felt unique in style.  

The story, meanwhile, is riveting and intense.  Sometimes too intense.  There is a scene with one of the antagonists midway through the game that is not friendly for younger children - and even caught me by surprise as an adult.  However, it equally fits with the story being told as a whole.  The story also has many exciting chase sequences.  It held me through the entire game and never once was I bored.

Controls: I used a game controller to play Never Alone.   Switching between the two characters was easy.  Using the bola was a little difficult, but became a fast learning experience during the many chase scenes.  Jumping and all the normalcies of a platformer were fine.  

The game is moderately difficult in terms of general puzzles and obstacles.   I died many times.   In the past I had issues with the AI, where the girl or fox would jump off a ledge trying to follow each other, but playing it shortly before writing this review yielded no issues.  The hints on where to stand or what to do were also extremely helpful and didn't make the game too easy by any stretch.   I imagine playing co op would make the game much easier in certain parts. 



Originally when I purchased Never Alone a long time ago, I was unable to play it because my video/graphics card couldn't keep up.  The AI was a pain, and there was lagging.  With a more up-to-date machine and game controller, and subsequent updates since the game's release, all of these problems went away, the game runs great, and I experienced no bugs or glitches during the entirety of playing.  


In short, Never Alone is a fun, quick 2d platformer with cultural insight, tense gameplay, and moderate difficulty.  It really is a gem in terms of games, and if you like the main story there is a bonus story in dlc.  If you're an achievement hunter, you cannot get all achievements without the dlc.

47680097.review:
It's a cool little game if you want to learn about a different culture rather than play a good game.

It's very similar to The Mooseman, actually. In both games, you're playing a mythological journey that is very light on actual gameplay, while collecting bits of information about the mythology and people behind the journey.

There are some puzzle and platforming elements, but they're not really the focus of the game, and aren't challenging.

From time to time, you will gain a new video, which is almost like a documentary fragment about one of the people of Alaska. The biggest difference between Mooseman and Never Alone is that the former is about a past culture (with archaeological evidence from the 7th-9th centuries), while the latter is about a still living community - although they are largely modernised by now, and the game is an attempt to "preserve" (although that isn't really a good word - perhaps "present" is more appropriate) their older traditions and values.

One very interesting aspect of these videos is how they tie the mythological journey with the rather mundane adventures of the people speaking, or their close ancestors (parents, grandparents at most). There was one particular story - about father and two sons being lost adrift in a piece of ice calling 911 (yeah, not very poetic!) and having a few hiccups but being ultimately saved. This is used in the game, where you're also lost adrift - although it is given a more poetic treatment and added to the overall "myth". This happens at several points - the videos either elaborate on something you see in the game (like the children spirits of the aurora borealis, or the context of hunting in the community), or provides a justification for it (like the drifting story).
It makes me wonder whether mythology itself may be created from these more mudane stories of multiple people into a single hero to represent them. Probably an element. Either way, this was a cool aspect!

The music isn't very traditional, which is unfortunate, but it still worked very well within the game and created a great atmosphere.

The graphics are cool as well, although they're tricky. Most of the background is blurry, so it could be rather unimpressive. Still, they manage to play with the colors in a great way, especially with the aurora and the underwater effects. Not the best looking game out there, but I found it surprisingly nice.

Finally, some of the scenes in the videos are really great and so are the colors.

Not much to say about gameplay. It's slow, and the DLC, which focused a bit more on gameplay and puzzles was rather tedious. Still, I had heard bad things about the companion AI in the game - I didn't have many problems. It's an okay game, although nothing worth playing for its mechanical strength of artistry alone. But the culture behind it surely makes up for it, and, as I said, they've managed to combine the game's journey with the videos presented in a very nice way that makes it worth playing!

Es un cuento narrado, temático y narrativo, una historia que se ha contado transformada en videojuego.
Está realizado en base a un documental y adquiere la etiqueta de mitad documental mitad juego.
Una gente fué a Alaska a hacer un trabajo documentativo sobre un pueblo que lleva subsistiendo varias generaciones en el ártico, cazando y en armomnía con la naturaleza, ayudándose los unos a los otros. En los ratos de ocio este pueblo suele reunirse y contar historias, pues el desarrollo literal de este juego es una de estas historias que ha sido contada por este pueblo medio tribu.

El documental sirve de guía para contextualizar y tematizar el juego, resultando bastante interesante esta exposición, pero sin embargo es demasiado... superficial y supersticioso, al final sólo se cuenta lo que se quiere que se vea.
Resulta demasiado subjetivo, adquiriendo el juego demasiada esencia posesiva. Lo describo en lo que se refiere a obra literaria como opaco e insípido. 
Por mi parte, no me gusta esta idea de hacer juegos que proyecten un trabajo original e independiente que ya tiene otro significado. El juego de alguna manera, deja de ser videojuego. 

La jugabilidad pués tampoco muestra ningún atisbo de poder contrarrestar esto. Está demasiado fragmentada y resulta demasiado discordante, discurriendo de forma farragosa y simple. Las cosas estan ahí, trabajando bajo un sistema crudo e inconsistente que pueda unir su práctica y funcion con elocuencia. 
El juego es de acción ligera y dinámica sobre plano lateral en scroll. El dinamismo se ejecuta respecto a lo que hay o sucede en el escenario y se tracude a modo de intuición en buscar lo que podemos hacer. El resultado es una dinámica comprensiva pero que evidencia poca intensidad por un sistema de juego crudo. 
El desarrollo es intervalado y es conllevado por la narración y el interés de qué sucererá después. A este interés de eventos se le acoplan algunas vistas del escenario muy hermosas que regularizan un impacto bastante bueno. 

Se propone de forma cooperativa para jugar. Se puede jugar en la misma pantalla en cooperativo o bien un jugador alternar el control de los dos personajes. Esta reseña está basada en haber jugado en modo un jugador. En cooperativo estoy seguro de que será más divertido y agradable al desvincular parte de esa dinámica comprensiva. Incidirá considerablemente hacia una jugabilidad entrelazada y conmutada. Cada jugador, mientras ve lo que hace el otro, se centrará en su propia misión y función.    


Nota: un 2,5
+1,0 general
+1,0 algunas vistas hermosas
+0,5 cosas que se aprenden sobre Alaska.

Índice de recomendación: 35%

Se trata de la adaptación de una leyenda, y el juego nos cuenta una sencilla historia a través de un escenario helado con diferentes mecánicas en cada zona. Si bien es cierto que trata un tema muy interesante y que la historia es divertida de seguir, también hay que comentar que Never Alone incluye vídeos a modo de mini-documentales que van surgiendo a medida que el juego avanza que sirven para comprender las alusiones y el contexto de la leyenda; la información aportada por los vídeos es bastante interesante, pero se desbloquean en momentos en los que cortan la historia e interrumpen el ritmo narrativo de esta.

En cuanto al apartado gráfico no puedo decir nada negativo: el juego cuenta con una estética trabajada, unos gráficos especialmente bonitos y una animación adecuada. El sonido es correcto aunque no destable, y la jugabilidad es sencilla pero útil; la única pega a este nivel viene de mano de las mecánicas y los puzzles, ya que son quizá demasiado sencillos y se vuelven rutinarios.

En un primer lugar llamó mi atención por el trasfondo y la intencionalidad del juego, que además entra muy fácilmente por los ojos. Sin embargo, no es adictivo sino más bien rutinario y las escenas de entrevistas rompen constantemente el ritmo narrativo. Dichas escenas se pueden obviar, pero si no se ven en el momento adecuado se pierde parte de la esencia de la historia; la idea original del juego es muy buen, pero el modo de llevarla a cabo no es el más adecuado. Además, debido a su carácter lineal, es muy poco rejugable. Never Alone es recomendable para aquellos que aprecien los juegos muy cuidados a nivel estético y para quien disfrute de las referencias culturales, para pasar una tarde entretenida (apenas dura unas 3 horas).

Le doy un 5/10 porque el apartado técnico está bastanta cuidado, me agradó especialmente que las escenas de vídeo entre niveles están en el idioma de los nativos que narran la historia, pero la simplicidad de los puzzles y la falta de ritmo hacen que no se disfrute en exceso.

If you are looking for a game to challenge your hand-eye coordination, or provide you with mind-bending puzzles, lower your expectations a little when starting this little gem. 

This is a game designed for casual gamers and/or children looking for a mild challenge while playing out a story; casual players will definitely enjoy the low difficulty curve, making this game very accessible to those first picking up a controller (regardless of age). A gamer will learn the basics required for most 2-D platforming games, though they may be dissapointed to learn that most 2D platformers aren't as story-rich as this experience.

Additionally, this game is best experienced with two players. The focus on friendship and teamwork in the adventure is prominent in any playthrough with another person, and the difficulty curve decreases when you only have to manage one character.

The educational aspect of this experience is not to be discounted; Gamification of education has found to create a more robust, "working" knowledge of a topic gamified. 41880825.review:
Never Alone was a charming and unexpectedly profound game, in which you play through the Inuit legend of Kunuuksaayuka, as told in the native language by the master storyteller. I learned a lot about the ways of life, traditions and values of those people, in a way I never anticipated. It gave me a real appreciation for a group of people that get little attention in our society, and I feel enriched for having experienced it. You will unlock portions of a documentary as you progress, containing interviews with tribe members discussing various aspects of their lives and community. It was very much worth watching them all, and gives much needed context to the game and your actions.

Gameplay-wise, the systems are pretty straightforward, but with a few unique twists. In single-player, you alternate between controlling the fox and the girl, in order to solve some platforming puzzles. Each one has different capabilities, such as the fox's ability to interact with spirits, and Nuna's thrown bola. With a second player, each one takes one character, and you will have to cooperate to get through. The gameplay was mostly pretty easy, but I actually died in certain sections more times than I would have expected to. Most of the time it was my fault, but occasionally some janky AI would send one character jumping to their death when I wasn't controlling them. I did also have a few moments where the controls did not respond fluidly, resulting in death. Minor frustrations like those aside, the puzzles are fun and creative, and overall not too taxing. Thankfully, you are never sent too far back when you die, and checkpoints come frequently.

The graphics themselves were serviceable, and for an indie 2.5-D platformer like this, I thought they looked well done. The art direction is fantastic, and really holds everything together. The cutscenes are done in an interesting scrimshaw style that lends itself well to the storytelling. The whole presentation really draws the player in. The music plays into this atmosphere, but there weren't many particularly memorable pieces in the score. It's definitely good, just not "amazing".

My overall impression of this game was very good, barring a bit of jank that didn't kill the experience. I was too involved with progressing through the story and learning more about the tribe to care too much about those few issues. I won't get into describing the story too much, but it reminds me of many other legends I've heard, complete with peril, good triumphing over evil, and moral lessons to tie it all together. The game is fairly short, at around 3 hours, including 24 short documentary clips. I'd say it's well worth your time if you choose to pick this up. You just might learn something while you soak in the experience! 8/10
