41651988.review:
[i]Never Alone[/i], or [i]Kisima Ingitchuna[/i], is a game that aims to educate as much as it does entertain. Based on an Iñupiat tale, a people native of Alaska, and narrated as such, [i]Never Alone[/i] is a puzzle-platformer that tells the story of a girl named Nuna and her fox companion, as together they brave many dangers to find the cause of a blizzard that is threatening her village. It's an experience perhaps better suited for co-op play -and indeed there is- as both Nuna and her fox have complementary abilities that will allow them to traverse the landscape. As you do so, you will encounter a series of owls that unlock short interviews about the Iñupiat people and their culture (beliefs, customs, way of life, etc.). Some of these are easily found, while other may take some additional exploring. Never Alone (Kisima Ingitchuna) is less of a game, and more of a storytelling experience. But do not let that deter you from diving into this wonderful cultural exhibit of the Inupiat people who are introduced in this story, their customs, their traditions, they values, their beliefs, their positive attitude, their hard-working nature, and their connections to everything else around them. The game has wonderful graphics, both in-game and in the animations. The animations contained two different styles, one to reflect the modern 2-D platforming game, and the other more traditional, likely to showcase the scrimshaw carvings that are used for storytelling, and through that, for them to educate their young. The game is accompanied by some great music and if you got the game with the DLC, then a few additional short but fun puzzles as well. The best part of the game involves the documentary "Cultural Insights" that are stories told from different perspectives, including personal recounts of growing up--both harrowing and fun. The deep connections that these people have with the nature around them, the living creatures, forces of nature, intertwined with their deep-seated beliefs, really provided for me quite an educational experience. 

The game does work with a controller, I played with the Steam controller and it worked without any problems. There were times when I felt that a second player could have helped out a lot instead of me having to switch between the two characters in a timely fashion in order to move on. As a result, one of the two characters perished (yes, you read that right) on multiple occasions. I got used to the controller, and so I did not want to switch to keyboard and mouse, which probably would have made it a little bit easier for parts. But hey, the game is short enough as it is, so having to replay a few parts was not a big issue. The Bola was a bit difficult to control on the Steam controller. That was my only complaint with the controller. I do not have an XBox controller, which would have made it a bit easier, I think. There were a few small bugs were I was clipped into a wall or got stuck for no reason, but the constant check-point system of the game made it easy to just restart from a few moments ago, and hardly caused any significant playability issues.

If you have been interested in this game (story, really), I think there are many reasons to emerse yourself in a different world, yet one that exists in reality on Earth, for a few hours.

38702302.review:
[h1]ANÁLISIS DE NEVER ALONE:[/h1]

Never Alone es más un juego cultural que un plataformas al uso, hay que tenerlo en cuenta desde el principio. Una vez sabido esto, Never Alone es un juego PRECIOSO, tanto estéticamente como por lo que representa. Vamos por partes:

[h1]Historia:[/h1]

Never Alone nos cuenta la historia de una niña llamada Nuna, que pertenece al pueblo de Iñupiaq del Ártico y sus aventuras junto a un zorro. Su objetivo es encontrar el origen de una ventisca eterna que está afectando a la vida de su pueblo. La historia está muy bien contada, además dotándola de mucha autenticidad al hacerlo en lengua iñupiac por un maestro cuentacuentos, todo ello subtitulado como es lógico (sí, está incluido el español entre los idiomas disponibles para subtítulos).

Además de la historia del juego en sí, Never Alone cuenta con muchos vídeos que iremos desbloqueando conforme vayamos avanzando, a modo de documental del pueblo de Iñupiaq mostrando a sus gentes, sus costumbres, vivencias y experiencias, además de historias y leyendas típicas de su folclore. 

[h1]Jugabilidad:[/h1]

Never Alone es un plataformas simple pero con algunos puzzles muy originales. Salta, agáchate para protegerte de las ventiscas, aprovecha las ráfagas de viento, usa al zorro para llegar a donde Nuna no puede hacerlo, etc. Hay que reconocer que (al menos bajo mi punto de vista), salvo dos o tres puzzles entre juego base y DLC, la mayoría de ellos son muy sencillos y no supondrán un reto a los que busquen algo más complejo.

Uno de los puntos más destacables de Never Alone, es que nos ofrece la posibilidad de jugarlo solos o con un compañero que controlará al segundo personaje, ya sea Nuna o el zorro ártico en cooperativo local. No he podido probar a jugarlo con teclado, pero con mando la experiencia es buena (yo uso el mando de XBOX 360). El juego se puede pasar perfectamente jugando solo como ha sido mi caso, teniendo que ir alternando entre ambos personajes para ir solucionando los puzzles que se van presentando. 

Como punto negativo, hay que decir que el control no responde todo lo bien que debería, provocándonos fallar muchas veces en los saltos siendo imprecisos. También en el aspecto de jugabilidad, sufriremos los fallos de la IA de vez en cuando, puesto que el personaje que controla el ordenador se quedará atascado, no avanzará, o "se suicidará" en más de una ocasión.

[h1]Sonido:[/h1]

El sonido cumple perfectamente siendo muy agradable, tanto la banda sonora (incluida en la edición Artic Collection) como el sonido ambiental y las voces que narran la historia. 

[h1]Gráficos:[/h1]

Never Alone usa el motor gráfico Unity, dando como resultado un conjunto muy bello. Los paisajes y modelados de los personajes están realizados con mucho mimo. Sin duda uno de los puntos fuertes del juego. El agua, hielo, nieve, las ventiscas, los bosques, lagos, fauna, el modelado de los personajes... todo es de una gran belleza, se nota que se ha hecho todo con mucho cariño.

Para no extenderme más, os dejo a modo de resumen mi lista de pros y contras:

[h1]PROS:[/h1]

- Estéticamente es muy bello

- Es una bonita historia

- Los valores que transmite

- Los personajes secundarios del folclore iñupiaq

- El zorro

- Los pequeños documentales que incluye y que podremos ir desbloqueando conforme avancemos

- Tiene logros Steam

- Se puede jugar en cooperativo en el mismo PC

- Traducido al español

- Se puede encontrar muy barato en época de ofertas, junto con el DLC y la banda sonora

- Tiene cromos Steam

[h1]CONTRAS:[/h1]

- La IA del personaje que controla el ordenador a veces falla

- Algunos bugs en las físicas

- No tiene cooperativo online

- A veces tiene bugs que impiden avanzar, obligándonos a salir del juego y volver a cargar la partida (me ha pasado un par de veces, una en el juego base y otra en el DLC)

- El control podría estar más pulido

- Puede hacerse algo repetitivo

- Es demasiado fácil, no supondrá un reto a los jugadores experimentados en plataformas

- Es muy corto, en 3h y media como mucho lo tendrás terminado sin demasiados problemas

[h1]Conclusión:[/h1] 

Never Alone me ha parecido un juego muy interesante por la parte cultural, por hacerme conocer más de cerca las tradiciones y costumbres del pueblo Iñupiaq del Ártico. Como juego de plataformas me ha parecido bastante simple y facilón, aunque original en algunos apartados y de una gran belleza visual. El conjunto es bastante bueno y merece mucho la pena, siempre que tengamos en cuenta desde un principio que se trata de un título más cultural y de caracter divulgativo que de un plataformas clásico. Ideal comprarlo en ofertas a precio reducido y especialmente en su versión Artic Collection, que incluye el DLC Foxtales (a continuación incluyo el análisis) y la BSO.
----------------------------

First actual game that I'm reviewing in my conquest to review all the games I've 100%'d.

- Definitely original later on into the game

A story-focused platformer. Not exactly unique in the gaming industry. However, games focused on the arctic and Inuit culture are more rare. Unfortunately, despite the beauty and cultural immersion, the game doesn't provide a worthwhile experience.

PROS:

+ Gorgeous Graphics. I don't believe I've ever seen such beautiful images. The character models are incredibly detailed and the motion is extremely smooth.

CONS:

- Bad Platforming. You could call this a "heavy" platformer, similar to Trine. The controls are slow and there is a lot of physics going on. Unfortunately, this game is way "heavier" than Trine. The physics are outright frustrating.
- Poor Game Design. So you have a heavy platformer, which already makes the controls difficult to handle. Then the designers had the great idea of making a primary mechanic be a blizzard. Which makes the controls even more difficult to handle. And kills you occasionaly, since you have to be watching extremely carefully to find the pattern.
- Lackluster Story. The story isn't anything special. It's a retelling of an Inuit tale, which is fine, but nothing stellar. And it's completely linear, so there are no choices at all to be made.
- Mediocre Music. I can't remember it. It does nothing for the game.
- Glitchy Death Sequences. Sometimes they triggered and you saw the second character cry before the screen faded to black. Sometimes there was an abrupt flash and you found yourself back at a checkpoint. 
- Stunningly Stupid AI. In the vein of many games recently, there are two protagonists and you must switch between them to complete the puzzles. Unfortunately, the AI is extremely poor. It killed itself on several occasions, and would often just stop following you forcing you to switch characters just to move through a level.

CONCLUSION;

This game could have been better. Much better. It could have been quite enjoyable, though it's so linear. But the gameplay ruined it. Bad AI, glitches in the cutscenes, and physics-based puzzles in a game with bad physics makes for poor gaming.

FINAL RATING: 2/7

Never Alone (Kisima Ingitchuna) is an atmosheric adventure platformer with some minor puzzeling aspects. It revolves around a girl named Nuna and a fox that desides to help her on her journey to find the source of what is overwelming her village with a never-ending blizzard. This can be played both single player and co-op (locally). It tells a traditional story of the Iñupiat, who are an Alaskan Native people, and gives video insights throughout the game to tell you more about the members of the Alaskan Native community's culture, values, and wisdom.

It took me about two and a half hours to get through the main game. An extra hour is me going through a certain section again to get an insight video that I missed, and to take some screenshots, as well as buy the DLC (Never Alone: Foxtails). The DLC is about an hour long and I got the rest of my time from going over the last section in the DLC to get more screenshots.

Overall, I really enjoyed the game, the art/graphics (while a bit outdated), still look fairly good considering the passage of time and the general budget of Indie titles. I enjoyed the story and getting to know more about the Iñupiat culture. I loved the connection between the girl and the fox and their personal journies through the environment. I've read a lot of people talking about the controls, and although I see their grievances to some extent, it never bothered me all that much. For the most part, I was able to do as I needed to progress through the game. There were times where I would die because I wasn't quite sure where to go, but I felt like it was either my fault for not getting it, or just a part of discovering what to do because the game decided to let you figure some stuff out on your own. That isn't to say it was completely hands-off either, because when I died on a particular part a couple times it would give visual hints of what I needed to do. There was only a very rare occasion where I knew what to do but couldn't do it but of how precise you had to be. These situations mostly happened in the last section. At that point I did get a bit frustrated, but it didn't even come close to overshadowing the good parts of the experience (which was a vast majority of the game).

The menu is a bit troublesome in my opinion because you have to use arrow keys, where with the rest of the game you are using WASD, so it was a bit unintuitive and confusing. There are settings and options for graphics, audio, ect. and it was all pretty standard so there really isn't anything to complain about there.

Despite the negatives I mentioned, I personally recommend this game, because I enjoyed it regardless of these minor (in my opinion) inconveniences. However, I would say you need to understand this game is more about the journey. If you are someone who gets frusterated easily you might not enjoy it because the moments where the game isn't flawless might blind you from seeing the rest of the game. Considering the game is only about three hours to complete (and giving the negatives above) I would reccomend it on a sale.

Never Alone is an adventure platformer consisting of some light puzzle solving and a blatant disregard for solid gameplay principles. It's hard to control but easy to love.

Built on the rich Inuit culture, Kisima Ingitchuna encompasses art, story, language, characters based on the history and folklore of those peoples. The presentation of this is mostly done in a solid manner. Inuit art and language are used for cutscenes as well as the story being a traditional Iñupiaq tale. By playing the game, unlockable videos also provide insight into some of the concepts and items behind the game.

The gameplay takes place in a 2D tundra world where obstacles provide the meat of the light puzzle solving where not too much thinking is required. The basic concept here being switching between Nuna and Fox where both have their own skills to help the other. The theory being when you move one, the other will follow (if you opened the path for them). This however does not always work as expected as I found myself having to switch between characters frequently as the other would just not do what I wanted and sometimes even killed themselves. The developers did include a local co-op mode so the second character can be controlled by a human. I recommend you try that.

Controlling the characters is a whole other can of beans. Characters feel heavy when moving, shooting the Bola is imprecise, swimming is.. well lets just say Mario would win gold in Olympic swimming on his day off after he had too much to drink the night before, Luigi would be second, Nuna and Fox would be disqualified for drowning. Controlling the kayak (DLC) is basically impossible.

Never Alone does a beautiful job of presenting itself. It has an unique concept tied to it and the execution of its artistic values are done well. Technically, it's a bit of a mess especially in the controls department. Gameplay is passable but too shallow for my taste. It's weak in puzzles and platforming and can hardly stand on its own adventure. There's no real depth to anything apart from the story if you can delve past the ambiguity of it. It's a shame because it is artistically very pleasing.

I don't think the game is worth the full price but you should try it just the same. If nothing else, it does provide insight into Inuit culture and hey, you can play as a fox.

[h1]Never Alone Review.[/h1]

[table]
[tr]
[th]Pros:[/th]
[th]Cons:[/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Wonderful narration.[/td]
[td]Occasional unresponsive controls.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Thought-provoking puzzles.[/td]
[td]Weak plot.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Amazing cutscenes.[/td]
[td][/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[h1]Lore[/h1]
Never Alone is a puzzle-adventure genre game that places you in a beautiful world on the brink of disaster. The story revolves around a child who becomes separated from her village during a devastating blizzard. Luckily, she's rescued by a seemingly magical Snow White fox. The primary objective of the game is to find the unknown source of the blizzard and stop it at any cost necessary. Throughout the game, you're able to switch between playing as the child and the white fox. Quite a few puzzles actually require you to do so in order to navigate through them.  

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
While the gameplay is very straightforward, I honestly found the simplicity enjoyable and preferred in this scenario. During gameplay, you're forced to navigate through multiple puzzles that are thought-provoking and intertwined with the plot. Completing these puzzles will progress you through the story and unlock absolutely amazing cutscenes that further develop the narrative. Throughout the game, I had experience with controls occasionally being unresponsive and frankly unusable for a certain duration. Even though it's a disappointing defect, I found the game amazing nonetheless.

[h1]Narration/Audio[/h1]
The narration in Never Alone is heart-wrenching and soul-defining. From the moment I started the game, I was hooked and unable to stop listening to the beautifully composed narrative. Furthermore, the music they incorporated into the gameplay is perfectly suited for the atmosphere that's demonstrated within the game.

[h1]Summary[/h1]
Never Alone is a beautiful demonstration of how a puzzle-adventure game is done correctly. I was pleasantly pleased with everything the game had to offer, and while a few defects are present, I genuinely don't believe they're a significant issue. Overall, for the reasonable price of 14.99$, I would highly recommend Never Alone to anyone who enjoys a casual puzzle experience with a twist. 

[h1]General: 7/10[/h1]

tl;dr - The bugs/design flaws made me want to rip my hair out at times, but the presentation and simple gameplay were enough to still make me really enjoy the game. A simple but enjoyable title, but I would wait for a sale, as $17 CDN seems a bit much for a game that I finished in 2 hours.

Never Alone is an adventure platformer, with inspirations from games like Limbo from the way the game progresses and its ominous atmosphere with bits of puzzles and action sprinkled throughout. I highly recommend playing it with a friend. Not because you like your friend. But you need someone to take control rather than letting the AI sit and drool. Also make sure they take Nuna. The fox is much more fun.

The game overall [i]is[/i] fun, but honestly, I would recommend this game as I grind my teeth. I don't regret playing it, and will probably come back to it later just to snag the last few achievements and play Foxtales, but that'd be it. The puzzles are mediocre, the platforming can be incredibly frustrating at parts, and there are a few bugs here and there that can halt the progress at times.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

As I was saying, the gameplay itself is alright. I found myself really annoyed with the wind mechanic, as even though there is a pattern to it, it does occasionally change, or sometimes, because of the level design, it can basically make you over-jump a gap and end up dying anyway because you flew right over the platform you were aiming for. The magnet mechanic to try and help you avoid falling over the edge can also be a pain, because at times it can make trying to make moving around a bit clunky as you might end up sticking to the edge for a moment and lose some momentum. Overall it's not terrible, but it feels like it could use some polish.

Also mentioned before, choose the Fox if you have a [strike]slave[/strike] friend to [strike]do all the tedious work[/strike] help. He's a lot more fun and feels better to move around with. I understand why Nuna doesn't move around as much, given her giant parka she's in, but nonetheless feels more fun to be able to leap around, wall-jump and get to do some of the more interesting work. 

[h1]Presentation[/h1]

This was probably my favourite aspect of the game. I really love how the game presents itself. It does have that Limbo sort of feeling with the calm and quiet atmosphere, which is a refreshing feeling and change of pace. You don't feel too rushed and you can enjoy the scenery. The spirits that help you along the way are simple yet charming, Nuna and the fox are simple in design but look really nice. One character that I thought was a little off was [spoiler] the man who attacks Nuna's village.[/spoiler] I understand he's supposed to be bad and therefore unlikeable, but I feel like he just stood out a bit too much. Overall though, I love the look of the game. It doesn't try to be anything extravagant, and that's okay. It's simple but charming presentation is beautiful and definitely pleasing to take in all throughout the game.

[h1]Bugs / Issues[/h1]

This is the part where I almost considered giving it a thumbs down, but I do feel it wasn't bad enough to sour my whole experience. When I played with my girlfriend, we'd find that sometimes Nuna would get stuck on platforms when she's climbing on spirits, I got glitched off and would fall to my death. I also mentioned in the gameplay section how the wind screwed me over occasionally as well. There is usually calm air with - I believe - a rhythymic gust that comes along every so often. One thing that I found, however, is that during some parts there's also this tiny little blow of wind that can impede your momentum, which isn't really used for anything. So I had a few instances where I was going to leap for a platform, and it's like the game poked me during midair and said "lolbye." I had this happen a few times and it just felt annoying.

The camera is fairly solid, but there were I think two areas where it wasn't really clear where I had to go, and ended up going towards a small platforming area where I needed the fox to show the spirits before we went. There was one spirit rope that you would fling across, but there was a second one you needed to reveal to make it to the other side of the gap. We thought that maybe you just needed this stupidly precise jump to be able to clear it, but after we went back a little bit and checked out the area above, [i]then[/i] it showed up, despite not doing so before.

Another thing was the Insights. I couldn't actually play any of them because it would just result in a black screen with nothing going on, so I simply restarted the game. There are 20-some of them and they look interesting, but I can't even check them out, which is unfortunate. I had to go on YouTube to see them.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

Despite my incessant whining, I really did enjoy Never Alone. I'm usually playing a lot more hardcore games, but I got Never Alone as part of a bundle, and I think you should do the same, or at least wait for a sale. It only took me 2 hours to beat the game, and if I wasn't dawdling, I could have probably finished in an hour and a half. It's a lot to pay for so little gameplay. If you do get a chance to get the game for cheap, I would definitely recommend it for a quiet night where you want to wind down with a simple story and relatively calm progression.

Fox/10, wouldn't play again, but enjoyed the first ride anyway.

Never Alone is a game that comes from the cold Arctic, made and written by members of the Iñupiat people (an indigenous group to Alaska and Canada, sometimes called "Inuit"). I love the creative direction of this game. It is an E X P E R I E N C E. From the art to the soundtrack, the presentation was high quality, and these elements delivered a cohesive vision about the spiritual connection that humans have with the world around them. There is something so lonely yet comforting about the game and its embodiment of this message. Just thinking about the title screen, I can feel a tug on my heartstrings, and I can hear the soft piano track playing in the background. The high production value also manifests in other aspects of the game. Everything just looks really nice, from the art to the level design to font choice and to the documentary videos that you unlock as the story progresses.

With that said, some people may be turned off by the game-documentary-game-documentary format that is pushed by the developers. I didn't really mind it when I was playing it, but I do think it limits the "fun" of the game in a sense. On one hand, the short videos explained cultural elements of the levels, making my experience more enriching. Because of the background provided, the storyline and spiritual elements made sense.

Characterization was a little lacking; I didn't even know Nuna's name until I saw it on gamefaqs. You don't really get the antagonist's reason for being evil, either. Both simply exist because legend said so. I think the devs deliberately made this trade off to push the educational aspect of the game. Personally, I don't see why they couldn't do both. What I will commend them on, however, is fostering a relationship between the player as Nuna and her fox without having them say a word. This animal is your only companion in a bleak and grim world. It reminds me of Wander and Agro from Shadow of the Colossus.

In terms of level design, the game was easy to medium difficulty as a puzzle platformer. I felt that the solutions were intuitive, and you would quickly learn what to do and what not to do when interacting with spirits. There were only a handful of times where I got stumped to the point where I looked the answer up. I will say that the whiteness of the snowy backgrounds did make it hard to see both A) the solution and B) death-inducing parts of the environment. I can't tell you how many times I acidentally jumped into icicle spikes, thinking those were in the background.

Regarding my frustrations, I was mainly more upset by the controls, as I found it extremely easy to fall off and die if you did not climb juuust high enough before jumping off a ledge. Keep in mind, however, that I am FAR more jump-death prone than other gamers.

The story is a spin on an old folktale of the Iñupiaq spoken to the player in the native tongue, and when combined with the unusual but amazing (and occasionally haunting) aestetic, it weaves a tale that entrances its audience, leaving them wanting more. I could go into detail, but it's best to play it yourself. Additionally, the "collectables" (little owls hidden throughout each level) unlock cultural context and some history from interviewed indigenous people. 

It's an interesting game, and I enjoyed my time playing. However, unless you feel compelled to buy it at 15~18$ immediately (for the base game, or the base game + DLC/Soundtrack, respectively), it may be best to wait for a sale to bring the prices down, maybe around 10$ for everything, or so.

33525412.review:
"For beautiful eyes, look for the good in others; for beautiful lips, speak only words of kindness; and for poise, walk with the knowledge that you are never alone."
-Audrey Hepburn


**Contains Spoilers**

Never Alone (Kisima Inŋitchuŋa) was a beautiful and informative 2D platformer with a two character system that has you swapping between the fox and the girl to achieve different tasks. This could be done with two players and I honestly think that would make the experience more enjoyable because at times you have to swap very quickly and move the characters a bit far to get through different obstacles. This would be much more seamless with a second player taking care of the different tasks while you focus on the tasks of one.

It does a great job teaching you all about the culture of the indigenous people of Alaska, the Inupiaq. It swaps back and forth between gameplay and live action video of people from the tribes explaining life in the brutal conditions. Learning about this lifestyle is really what kept me personally interested until the end. It was so cool to hear them talking about how they are able to hunt for food in the month of November when there is no sunlight for the entire month. This among other anecdotes from the native people was a very entertaining addition and I believe that it gave the game an extra bit of depth than it would not have had otherwise.

The young girl and the fox set off on a journey that is an old tale of folklore called Kunuuksaayuka passed down by the elders. It is traditionally a boy in the story but for the video game they decided to have the protagonist be represented as a girl. The girl comes home after being chased by a polar bear to find that her village has been burned to the ground and destroyed. She runs into a man wearing a mask who inexplicably knows who she is and asks her to retrieve a drum of his that some mischievous little guys stole from him.

After finding and returning the drum the girl is presented with the bola, which is used to open many ice covered areas in the game, and is traditionally  a weapon used for hunting. An evil man soon catches up to the girl and it becomes clear that the man was looking for the bola when he burned her village to the ground. The girl and the fox make a break for it using the new weapon to aid them in their journey moving forward.

A very beautiful section of the game comes when the girl and the fox come across the Northern Lights. A phenomenon that is clearly visible from Alaska and is tied into the gameplay in a very interesting way. They say that the Northern Lights would come down and grab the children if they ventured too far, surely as a means to keep them close to the adults and not wandering off into hostile territory. So to tie this in they made the Lights fly around the screen leaving a green trail everywhere it goes. If you come across the front of the trail where there is a face and arms pictured, you will be snatched up by the lights, just as in the old tales of the elders. An interesting touch and it made for some very beautiful level designs.

After a perilous journey, tragedy strikes and (spoiler: highlight to reveal) the fox dies after a hard fall. The girl is heartbroken but as in the title she will learn that she is never alone even when her dear friend has passed on. The spirit of the fox comes to aid her on the rest of the journey and we are taught a valuable lesson that the natives believed about the spirits of animals. From this point on the floating spirit is the second player.

This leads to a bunch of new and cool mechanics, such as obviously the flying around to any point on the screen, but there are many other things it introduces as well. The fox can awaken the spirits of the land and help by moving things to help the girl get around, such as the branches of a tree or something to get a grip while climbing up the side of a mountainous area. I wasn't sure I was going to like this change at first, but when I saw all of the different mechanics that it brought along with it I was sold. The change helps to bring a sort of new life to the game when you are starting to get a little bit burnt out on doing the same types of environmental puzzles with the two characters.

So the apparent mission of the two is to hunt down whatever might be causing the everlasting blizzard that has been plaguing all of the people. After searching long and hard and finding their way through many strange and difficult environments, they come across the answer. There is an Ice Giant that is constantly hammering away at icy mountain tops, causing the incredible snowfall and wind that has made it so hard to reach this point.

The girl notices a way to get up to the hammer of the giant and with the help of her spirit friend she climbs up and knocks it out of his hands. The two make their way to the hammer and are able to damage it so that the giant can not use it to cause the terrible blizzards anymore and the girl is immortalized as a hero to the people. It wasn't a very long game but the story is rich with culture and history, it makes for a very unique experience and the gameplay was good enough to at least keep you going as you uncover more and more about this unique sect of people who have endured such a harsh and rugged land.

33504887.review:
[i]Never Alone[/i] is an linear light puzzle platformer with the Alaskan Natives' culture and mystical elements. 

The game does well in being a puzzle game; it offers appropriate difficulties, ensuring it can be enjoyed by the masses rather than the hardcore minority. However, what makes [i]Never Alone[/i] stands out is not only the game itself; it is all the cultural elements integrated in the gameplay, the story, the setting, and the art style. 

The killer point of this game: it offers [b]minute-long documentaries about lives, values, and cultures of the natives as well as elements in the game.[/b] The documentaries are offered as collectables that present themselves in the game as owls. This provides both an incentive to unlock all achievements and an unique opportunity to peak into the lives of the Alaskan Natives, who remain in hunting-gathering lifestyles till this day. 

The short documentaries, known as "Cultural Insights" in the game, total to a number of 30, including those in the Foxtale DLC. The documentaries paint a vivid picture of the Alaskan native culture and the people thereof, and it immediately sparked my interest. [b]The clips reveal values and philosophies of the native people[/b], which could very well lend insight to the lives of us city-dewellers. I may not play the game itself again, but I probably will watch the clips again.

In the game there are two controllable characters, the girl and the fox. If you are playing alone, you alternate between the characters to solve the puzzles. [b]The game also offers a cooperation option[/b], so you can play with your friend, family, or boy/girlfriend if you have one. I don't.

[b]Be sure your FPS is high for this game.[/b] If you have a bad computer like I do, you will get very low performance. As a result, the controls become delayed and unresponsive. This is DAMAGING to the gameplay. For a lot of my hours spent on the game, I wrestled with the controls. But please beware of the fact that this is my problem, not the game's.

[b]The Foxtale DLC is a must-have.[/b] I picked up both during summer sale for an insane price, and it is worth every penny even if I bought it for the original price. The DLC offers a new story with the same characters and another hour of gameplay, while revealing more insights into the native philosophy. I personally feel that the puzzles in the DLC is more fun to solve than whose in the original game.

Overall, [i]Never Alone[/i] is a casual game that is fit for all to play. If you like puzzles, casual games, love documentaries, and/or have a boy/girlfriend, I strongly recommend this. 

9/10

32092891.review:
This was a very well-meaning game that should have been a documentary or a kid’s show or something, because it was a terrible platformer with possibly the worst control layout I’ve ever experienced. Road to hell is paved, etc etc.

The idea with this game was to tell a Native Alaskan folktale with the input of the actual Native Alaskans. That’s a lovely sentiment, and indeed the game is interspersed with video of the people talking about their culture. These videos, dubbed “Cultural Insights,” were really cool and interesting, and were easily the best part about the game (edit: except in that they had to be unlocked by triggering random waypoints, which was really annoying when they were the highlight).

The art was also very nice, though the 3D models themselves were awkward.

The problem is literally everything else.

First of all… okay. So you move around with your left hand and the normal WASD controls. But the “interact” button is the left shift key. Not either shift key, not the right, the left. This meant that to interact with the environment, you either had to cross your right hand over, take your hands off the arrow keys, or contort your hand so that you could, say, hold W, D, and LS at the same time. I have small hands, but I am confident that after hours of this anyone would be uncomfortable. I literally was still in pain the day after I played, not joking.

Meanwhile, You use the space bar to jump and the left mouse button to attack. So while your left hand is playing Cirque du Soleil, your right is hopping back and forth between the mouse and the keyboard, all in a vain effort to play the damn game.

MEANWHILE, the key to toggle character modes is Q, while is right next to W, so as you’re flailing around trying to jump and drag and walk to the right at the same time, you may just accidentally swap to another character somewhere else on the map. Then you die.

Like… I know this may not sound bad because I’m not sure how to describe four hours of increasing pinky pain and utter frustration, but I don’t think this is a complaint I’ve ever made on this blog before, or in my life before, so try to give me the benefit of the doubt.

Meanwhile, when the controls did work physically, they were incredibly clunky and unreliable in the game. Often I had to press the mouse button several time to get one attack off, jumps seems to execute whenever they felt like, and the physics were just not. This game is ostensibly a platformer, a genre that is predicated on quick, precise controls. Between the unreliable nature of the characters’ weights, jump distances, and speed, the question of whether or not button-presses would work, and the ridiculous layout, the game was almost unplayable. Forget about something like timing jumps. It was so fucking frustrating.

Meanwhile, so, there’s two player characters. At all times, one of them is controlled by the single stupidest AI ever, and if the AI dies it counts as a death. So much of my time was a race to the next save point before the AI committed suicide. So. Much. There were also parts of the game where the two characters had to be close together or the platforms would disappear. The AI seemed to get great joy out of wandering off and letting me fall to my death. Over. And over. And over.

The game is also really buggy. Sometimes when you’d jump to cling onto a wall, the sprite would hit the wall, flail in the air for 10 seconds, and then die, even if there was ground right underneath. There was a whole area of wall-climbing that was just the most Sisyphean exercise in futility. There was also one point where I was standing on solid ground waiting for a platform to come close, and I just fell through the ground into the level below. Just, plop, into the hillside and out the bottom.

Another big issue is that there was very little sense of gameplay progression. Large swaths of the game are just walking through barren snowscapes, and every once in a while there will be a platform you have to jump to. There’s not much of an increase in difficultly as things go on, and new mechanics are introduced very sparingly. Then there’s the narration that actually tells the story, which is really, really widely dispersed. Every fifteen minutes or so the narrator would spout of two “And then this happened…” lines and then disappear forever, something no doubt made worse by the billion times I died. Then there’s the cultural videos, which are a few minutes long apiece.

The end result is that the pacing is terrible. I’d love to see the entire script for the game; it’s probably just a few pages. This game took me four hours to play, and virtually nothing happened. You’d think that working with folklore there’s be a lot of interesting and exciting plot events to throw in, but the vast majority of the game was just walking in silence. It never really feels like you’re getting anywhere; the protagonists don’t feel like they’re accomplishing anything. Hell, it feels like they’re at the whim of the narrator, not the setting itself; they have no real agency or personalities, no real emotions we’re shown, they just walk, then stop for two lines of narration, then walk some more.

One thing I really don’t think the game considered is that these stories that come from oral traditions are meant to be experienced all at once. When in between the old woman (well, man, but I picture it as a woman) dramatically giving her monologue you intersperse (frustrating) video game, you lose something that I think is really integral to the experience. The whole thing is disjointed, as though the game, the storytelling, and the real people we’re seeing on video all have nothing to do with each other.

I guess I’m just kind of confused about the way this was told. Why doesn’t the girl get any lines? Why doesn’t the villain? Why not make her, the character, the way through which this story is told (as one would expect) and use the narrator as a bridging event, for time jumps and to skip the “walking through barren snowscapes” thing that sucks so much? I think whoever was behind this had the idea of what they wanted to do — Alaskan folklore, with the Alaskan people, in video game form — but really had no idea how to weave those things together in a coherent whole. The result is something that even awful gameplay aside is less than the sum of its parts.

So… yeah. Skip the game. But go watch the cultural videos, I’m sure they’re online somewhere, and they’re wonderful.

Never Alone is a visually attractive game, but it has major flaws in mechanics and interactions. First, game control, especially for single players, is really irritaing, because the player has to switch between the two main characters. Once you are in control of one, the other moves purely on AI, which often falls behind the character being in control, and fall off platforms. This causes the player to have to replay the scene from the check point. 

Moreover, there are times that the AI-controlled character just stands still and the scene is fixed, restraining the other character (in control) from progressing. This, once or twice, has resulted in death of the character from hitting the constraint and falling.

The characters' reaction when the other one dies is highly unrealisticm which really agitates me. The fox/ the girl whines when the other dies wherever they are, even when they are not supposed to see the death, e.g. they're facing the other way or they are behind walls. Some people might not care, but this really bothers me (sorry for the rant.)

The narrative of the game is based mainly on cutscenes. The game itself doesn't provide much additional information that would keep the player intrigued. There are collectable short documentaries (which I honestly don't watch because it is complete separated from the game and watching them while playing would take away the flow, but that's my personal preference. I'm sure they are informative, but I just don't like watching it while playing. I prefer having the game telling the information, not documentary videos.) 

In the game, most levels are highly repetitive, with the same jumping and running over and over again. There are quite a few chasing scenes, which requires the player to perform the same task over and over.
New methods are introduced intermitently, but they become overused after a while. 

Game levels are puzzle-based, with in-between scenes where you just run. The puzzles aren't so intuitive, plus there are hints available, which is good in case you're stuck. Nevertheless, the character movements are really slow, and the graphic response isn't really good. There are times I try to jump over rocks and stuck mid air, doing glitchy moves, before falling into pits; or trying to jump to the wall with the fox, but falling directly into the water; or getting confused with the preset movement, especially getting up from water (which requires the player to press W, while sprinting uses SPACE, which results in me jamming SPACE, trying to get up.)

The 2.5D platformer puzzle game style reminds me of Limbo or Inside, with a more heartwarming story line. However, the puzzles in Never Alone, I emphasize, are way less complex, and the story progress slower. 

For me, this game lacks components that would keep the players interested for a long time. It has nice aesthetic and eye-opening storyline, but the simplicity and lenghtiness, combined with uncompromising puzzle game mechanics take away the experience.

The portrayal of these indigenous people and their culture is fantastic. I loved unlocking and watching each little piece of footage that provided further exposition to the game, to the history of its story, and to the people it is based on.

[i]Never Alone[/i] is a lovely little game where a lot of patience and care has been put into its design and development. It never outstayed its welcome and the mechanics of the game were changed up often enough to keep things interesting to the very end. [i]Never Alone[/i] should always be played together with a friend, never alone.

*Disclaimer* I played this game co op, with controllers, so I did not encounter any single player AI bugs, nor did I have any problems with controls. If you have read any negative reviews about the controls or the AI being buggy, just play it with a controller and co op and you'll be fine. Also, playing through this very few bugs were encountered, only one was, and that was not being able to watch the final cutscene in Foxtales (the DLC), which wasn't even in the main game, and we just watched the cutscene on YouTube.

Never Alone (Kisima Ingitchuna) is a beautiful game, not just in graphics, but in everything about it. The educational value of the game, the co op gameplay, and the resistance to being Westernised were all great reasons this game is amazing!

The educational aspect of this game is very well done. The more you play, the more videos you unlock. The videos are people speaking about their culture, stories in their culture, and explaining what exactly is going on in the game. This is a perfect way to learn about different cultures, as it gives the marginalised a voice for talking about their experiences, and it gives us context. Never do the videos feel like they are interupting the gameplay, as the videos are often found when you are not doing anything particulary important. Nor are the videos a chore to find, never while playing this did we have to look up a guide for the videos. The videos also were never a chore to watch, but always a pleasure, as it gave a nice little bit of context to what you were doing in game.

The gameplay itself was amazing, especially playing co op (I have played only up to the fox being introduced singleplayer, the rest I have played co op). The game was made for being co op and works best that way. No single character is used more or less in the game, and each player feels like they have an equal and important role in the game. Despite this being my account, I even played second player myself, because animals are awesome! While my co op buddy played Player One, and at no point was I bothered. I quite enjoyed playing second player, as the fox has so many great roles, such as moving spirits, wall jumping, and [spoiler] flying! [/spoiler] But player one also has so many great roles, such as throwing the bola, pushing things (and paddling in Foxtales, which my co op buddy told me was a lot of fun). Despite the controls being very minimal, the game never felt constricted or empty. 

Although I, myself, am not a part of any cultural minorites, the game not letting itself be Westernised was a very important thing. The whole game is not in English, instead it is in the langauge of the Iñupiat people, but with English subtitles. I personally don't mind subtitles, and eventually get used to reading them, so this provided no issues for me, but did do a really good job of giving the native people an actual voice instead of giving it an English voiceover. Other ways that the game refused to Westernise was that the entire plot of the game was derived from an actual Iñupiat story, and the story wasn't changed to make it more interesting to a modern audience, because it didn't have to be changed, as it was perfect. As well as the beautiful story and the language, the game also had lovely art cutscenes, as well as the game cutscenes.

Overall, it was a very unique experience to play a game made respectfully and made beautifully such as this one. I loved learning about a culture that I was very unaware of, I loved the co op gameplay, as it made me feel good to share this wonderful game with someone, and I loved the authenticity of the game. Even if I tried I could not find any reason to hate this game, no bugs did we encounter, we did not get stuck too long while playing, and we both had a brilliant time while playing it. I would recommend this game to anyone who has: an open mind to learning about different cultures, a controller, and an IRL friend to play with.

Never Alone turned out to be an unexpectedly powerful game to me, despite some weaknesses in the controls and mechanics.

The main purpose of Never Alone is to paint some images of Iñupiat folklore and culture. The Iñupiat are an Alaskan Native group of people, and some of the developers of the game involved are actual members of the culture, with stories throughout the generations being passed down.

Nuna and Fox, a little girl and an actual fox, are setting out to learn what is behind a blizzard that is destroying her family's village. To play their adventure, you control both of them, or can play co-op with someone else.

In order to get around, the game is a 2.5D platformer, with some pretty nice graphics for nature and beings you come across. Most parts of the gameplay are nothing that new for platformers, as you switch back and forth between the characters to use a small number of unique abilities - i.e., Fox can wall-run and wall-jump, while Nuna can move objects or throw a bola (a netting of stones), to name a couple.

Most of your time is spent solving little puzzles to move forward. Many are easy, as they just involve having one of the two characters get to a place the other can't, then opening a path. Though there are some more unique challenges here and there to get through, such as non-material platforms that can be moved around with special capabilities. At a few points in time, the game also has some chase scenes which are enjoyable, but later ones in the game get to be a little picky and the flaws of the game's mechanics show up there a lot.

Speaking of, let's get into the gameplay flaws. While you should be able to complete the game in a few hours and not have that many problems, there are definitely a handful of places in the game where you will suddenly get angry. Certain places in the game require perfect jumping with the winds, for instance. But the game seemed to be inconsistent with the physics. You will clearly see when the wind is blowing in one direction or another, but sometimes the game will still keep the physics of the wind direction even when no wind is moving along the screen. When that happens, it will easily lead to you falling down, sometimes to your death.

The reliability of moving along the platforms is also finicky at best. Sometimes the character will glitch out and act as if they can't grab the ledge, usually ending with their death again. And even worse, the AI (whichever character you are not controlling at the time) will follow you along on its own, but sometimes move or jump at the wrong time, causing itself to die and making you restart a section.

I definitely got more frustrated as the game went along with the above issues happening more often, especially in slightly more challenging sections. Nevertheless, I was able to push along and still complete the game. Even the most glitchy sections did not hold me back that long.

But the only reason I did the above was what I mentioned at the beginning - the folklore, culture, and style. I believe that the developers made the game efficient in showcasing that, but by also making it connected as a game. It is not like you are just sitting and watching a documentary. Which is funny, because as you play the game, you unlock "Insight" collectibles, which are actually videos of developers, Iñupiat family members, and other people being interviewed about the game and the culture. Some clips and photos also show the areas of Alaska in modern times as well as from mid/late 1900's, it seems.

And yet I never felt bored or like I was just sitting through information. In fact, I felt emotionally attached to the story. So, I recommend Never Alone for a more unique style of game wearing the outfit of a traditional platformer.

Tl;dr version: 
There's good and bad with this game. It doesn't reach the heights of LIMBO due to the controls but isn't too bad. Buy on sale.

Long version:

At its core the game is a platformer with a lovely graphical design, an interesting premise and slightly mushy controls. 

The game is a joy to behold and that's the #1 thing it has going for it. The art style is beautiful and that carries over to the environments, characters and so forth. The premise - using native folklore - to traverse this beautiful world is also endearing. If you want there are a number of movies in the game that help you better learn the way of life and the lore behind this story. Frankly, I skipped those parts because I was not all that interested. I may very well go back and watch those videos later but I felt they interruped the core gameplay too much.

So...beautiful game, interesting premise, a chance to learn about another culture...is there a downside? 

It's the gameplay that's a little bit of a downer. The controls - even on a 360 controller - aren't tight as they are in LIMBO. If I died in LIMBO it was always due to my own fault. Here, I died quite a few times due to the controls being mushy. You control two characters for most of the story and one is often dependent upon the other. Yet this other will sometimes drift away and thus you die due to no fault of your own. The bola controls are truly hideous. 

The other downside of the game is that it's quite short. I finished the game in 2.6 hours and I'm not particularly good at these kinds of games. Because Never Alone doesn't have the same kind of emotional impact as something like LIMBO, I don't see any replayability in this title either so those 2.6 hours - unless I go back and watch the videos - are all that's going to be there. That's not very good for a game that sells for $15.

However, I bought it on sale at 80% off and at $2.99 it was worth the money. At full price I would be ticked off because there's not enough value here. On a sale that's above 50% off, it's worth your time.

28158898.review:
English review (polski jak zawsze, niżej)

Watching the Never Alone's ending credits I realized how much I am grateful for growing up during the 90s. Not for the bragging rights though. While many people criticize this game for clumsy and irritating controls (and not without a reason I must admit) I have seen the early platforming games with barely minimal physics and collision model inferior to what can be created in 20 minutes with the help of contemporary tools like GameMaker or Clickteam fusion. Truth be told, while I've seen much worse, Never Alone controls rather slow and switching between the game's two protagonists can be frustrating - especially in the final chapters of the game where the time limits are introduced. Consequently, if you are looking for a platform game with tight and responsive controls there are plenty better titles out there on Steam - the new Rayman games, Hell Yeah, Knytt Underground, the Shantae series or Odallus just to name the first few that come to mind. 

With that out of our way, how about some reasons to actually give Never Alone a try? First of all, while technologically rather simple, the graphics - aesthetically - are pretty charming. That is if you like glaciers and various shades of blue, and even then Ori and his Blind Forest beat Never Alone effortlessly. Music on the other hand is enjoyable and perfectly fits the game's mood and tone.  

Having mentioned that, the game is saturated to the brim with the folklore. The characters' designs , cutscenes resembling animated paintings, unlockable insights into the native Alaskan culture and beliefs or the storyteller narrating the entire adventure in the Iñupiaq language (accompanied by the subtitles of your choosing) - they make the entire game feel more like an interactive folk tale or fable. 

The gameplay and challenges are surprisingly varied and ( while only about three hours long) the game stays fresh and entertaining for the entire time. The special mention goes to the final two boss battles - or, boss puzzles, to be more precise. Shame the entire experience is hampered by the, above mentioned, controls. 

Long story short, I believe Never Alone deserves a chance, but definitely not at the original pricetag. It feels too short and clumsy for that. On the final note : if you enjoy the folklore games, may I suggest getting familiar with the Year Walk - also a folk - inspired game available here on Steam. Only much, much darker and more evil. Also, cheaper. 

Polska recenzja: 

Oglądając zakończenie Never Alone zdałem sobie sprawę jak bardzo się cieszę z faktu że dorastałem w latach 90tych. Podczas gdy wielu ludziom przeszkadza niezdarna mechanika tej gry (i trzeba przyznać, jest coś na rzeczy...), ja widziałem wczesne platformery posiadające ledwie konieczne minimum fizyki i model kolizji gorszy niż to co obecnie można zrobić w 20 minut w GameMakerze albo Clickteam Fusion. Dzięki temu, przez większość czasu Never Alone nie irytowało mnie przesadnie. Trzeba jednak przyznać że szybkość z jaką dwójka bohaterów reaguje na komendy gracza mogłaby być lepsza – szczególnie w końcowych rozdziałach gdzie gra wprowadza limity czasowe na pokonywanie przeszkód. Jeżeli więc do czerpania radości z gry potrzebujesz szybkiej i precyzyjnej mechaniki, jest pełno lepszych gier na Steamie – wszystkie Raymany, Hell Yeah, Knytt Underground, seria Shantae czy Odallus – to tylko kilka które przychodzą na myśl. 

Najgorsze z głowy. To może jednak warto dać Never Alone szansę? Pierwszym argumentem za jest grafika – z estetycznego punktu widzenia potrafi być naprawdę czarująca. To znaczy jeżeli lubisz lodowce i szeroką gamę odcieni błękitu, ale nawet wtedy Ori'emu z jego ślepym lasem może skoczyć. Muzyka za to świetnie wpasowuje się w kolejne rozdziały gry i pomaga budować nastrój.

Skoro już o tym mowa: twórcy stawiają na klimat. Never Alone jest wypełnione po brzegi i dokładnie nasączone gęstym folklorem natywnych ludów Alaski. Widać to w projektach postaci, po przerywnikach filmowych stylizowanych na animowane malowidła skalne, nawet narracja prowadzona jest w języku Iñupiaq(od początku do końca, z napisami w jednym z 16 języków – w tym polskim). Wszystko to sprawia wrażenie uczestniczenia w interaktywnej opowieści, czy może baśni – jeżeli lubicie takie klimaty, będzie to spory plus. 

Sama rozgrywka jest ciekawa a stawiane przed graczem wyzwania zróżnicowane (choć gra kończy się w mniej więcej trzy godziny, więc gdyby w tak krótkim czasie nudziła nie było by chyba większego sensu w ogóle zawracać sobie nią głowy. Z drugiej strony jeżeli graliście w Tulpę...). Szczególnie świetne są dwa ostatnie pojedynki (czy raczej łamigłówki umożliwiające pokonanie...) z bossami. Szkoda jedynie że wspomniane wcześniej sterowanie znacząco je utrudnia. 

Podsumowując; Never Alone zasługuje żeby dać jej szansę, choć zdecydowanie nie za cenę 15 euro. Jest na to zdecydowanie za krótka i momentami irytująca. Jeszcze jedno: Jeżeli lubicie gry eksplorujące obyczaje i tradycje zerknijcie na Year Walk, dostępną na Steamie, podobnie śnieżną, podobnie folkową, podobnie krótką ale dużo, dużo mroczniejszą i bardziej krwawą grę. Również tańszą.

The general glow and contrast is really nice and with all these things together it gave off a nice atmosphere.

There are puzzle elements to this game and it’s at these parts especially that I can’t imagine playing on my own. Me and my boyfriend had to co-ordinate and get certain timings right to be successful in some of the puzzles. Few games are simply this beautiful; from the wonderful art style, the crimshaw cutscenes, to the voiceover in the native Inupiaq language.  Even though the original intention was to bring the culture of native Alaska to the new generation, it still feels welcoming to outsiders who want to learn more about the peoples and lifestyle.  You are essentially playing a fairy tale.  That being said, the controls do leave a little to be desired, with some sections of the game bordering on the maddening.  But that is easily forgiven when you feel the satisfaction of solving a particularly difficult section.

However, what is easly my favorite part is actually the collectables.  Rather than having chests, or items that grant in-game bonuses, the collectables are a series of owls which, when found, unlock a documentary clip.  Those documentary clips serve as the perfect companion piece to the content of the game, featuring interviews and explorations of life in the far north of the United States.  It remains one of the few games that made me want to collect everything.

As a side-note, if you want to read more tales from the Inupiaq, as well as read the one credited with inspiring the game, I highly suggest checking out "The Dall Sheep Dinner Guest: Inupiaq Narratives of Northwest Alaska" by Wanni W. Anderson.  It is a collection of tales by native storytellers, including Wille Goodwin Sr., whose family were involved with the creation of "Never Alone."

A long while ago, I was given this game as a present. To me, it looked so sweet and particularly interesting because I have a very big soft spot for animals. While the game does live up to these two things, being sweet and a treat for anyone who appreciates animals, Never Alone is also something much more than that.

This game is a simple 2-D platformer with a storyline that was based on very old folklore. The developers of this game really took the time to immerse themselves into the words of the people who made this folklore and created something brilliant with it. Throughout the game you are given snippets of videos showing them interviewing people about their folklore and what exactly it all means. In the end you discover that the central idea of these stories was to unite people in the belief that you must respect all forms of life no matter how big or small.

There are a few really nice challenging parts of this game that I think also make the game very worthwhile. The plotline takes and unexpected shift and gives you a whole new sense of gameplay. If you buy the DLC, you will find that it is also a great addition to the game.

Overall, I think that this game is a lovely pick for anyone who is looking for something that isn't too challenging but has an interesting and thought-provoking ending. I recommend watching all of the videos as well because they help you to understand the developer's visions through the eyes of the people who inspired them. It also has a very soothing soundtrack.

I am happy to say that I got to experience this game and even more thankful that it was given to me as a present. It truly is a wonderful game.

It would be easy to be critical of this game - so here goes:
You play as Nuna, who cannot swim and will die within 1 second of contact with water, unless the plotline determines this to be inconvenient, in which case she can hold her breath underwater forever. Her friend, a happy companion fox, also cannot swim until it's convenient for the game to do so, and then is a slippery ice weasel.
The game will not progress until you do things the right way, specifically, the way the game's makers played it, presumably this being a game which had no QA testing, because in it's functional capacity as a platformer it is pretty darn broken. If, for example, you jump at the wrong time and land on a platform the game will not allow you to land on that platform because you jumped at the wrong time according to Game.
If you placed one of your characters too far away from the other, then the game won't allow your other character to complete certain jumping tasks, despite there being no obvious reason why this should be.

As a lesson in Inupiat culture, art, madness and wisdom, it's pretty darn solid. In fact, it's beautiful graphics are one of the better examples of matching mood to content that I've seen, and are culturally-appropriate. As a platformer however it's fairly simplistic, clumsy, and it did not surprise me that it was made in Unity - that being the Great Maw from whence all unpolished content which looks good ensues.
Other beefs: There's no option to change controls, meaning the game is barely playable for left-handers. There's no real 'flow' of direction to the game, and finding out what you're meant to do is more-or-less trial-and-error most of the time. And occasionally Fox will just wander off in the opposite direction to yours, for no apparent reason. In certain areas, if you are controlling the fox instead of Nuna, you'll insta-fail. The game uses 100% of all cores on your CPU at all times.
What's astonishing is that this game has been out several years - would be relatively easy to fix - but hasn't been. The new steam review system would make sure that it got the attention it deserves, if the issues were resolved.

So if you don't care about 'game', play this game - it's a good learning experience. 
If however you're the type that gets pissed off with clumsy controls and simplistic puzzles, give this one a miss.

26511503.review:
Puedes leer el artículo original en Legión de Jugadores: http://legiondejugadores.com/indie-rewind-never-alone-un-cuento-de-invierno/

Los cuentos son una de las formas más antiguas de la literatura. Surgidos de la necesidad del hombre de conocer, y darse a conocer a sí mismo, se han contado miles y miles de cuentos desde los inicios de la humanidad. Con la misión de transmitir valores y conocimientos, cada comunidad creó los suyos en base a su mitología o folclore. No era raro encontrar, en cada una de estas comunidades, a un sabio que se encargase de contar dichos cuentos y asegurar su supervivencia a lo largo de cientos — o incluso miles, como en este caso — de años.

Rozando este concepto se encuentra Never Alone, un trabajo que llegó a manos conjuntas de Upper One Games y E-Line Media durante el primer cuarto del pasado año, y que resulta en una suerte de cuento ártico nacido de Kunuuksaayuka, una historia tradicional de los Iñupiaq.  Explorando con acierto el folklore de estos nativos de la gélida región de Alaska, Never Alone nos lleva a vivir una aventura mágica donde el invierno solo se ve superado por la amistad de una joven y un pequeño zorro ártico.

De esta forma el juego nos pone en la piel de Nuna, una joven Iñupiaq que ya desde joven destaca en los campos de la supervivencia y la caza. Preocupada por las incesantes ventiscas que azotan su aldea y privan de alimentos a sus habitantes, la chica decide partir en busca del origen del desastre, sola y sin más ayuda que sus propias manos. La joven no tarda en encontrarse en problemas, pero cuando se encuentra a escasos minutos de acabar bajo las garras de un oso polar, un pequeño zorro ártico —al que me referiré cariñosamente como Fox— consigue distraer al oso para que la chica pueda escapar, forjando la base del título: la cooperación.

Una vez tomemos el mando después de encontrarnos con Fox el juego nos permite intercambiar el control entre él y Nuna para cumplir un desafío tras otro, que suelen representarse en forma de plataformas, puzzles y una original e interesante mezcla de ambos elementos. Encontramos también la opción de jugar de forma cooperativa, optando cada jugador por uno de los dos roles que nos ofrece el juego. Debo decir que la necesidad de cambiar de personaje de forma constante para resolver las dificultades que surgen durante el camino se traduce en un incentivo para completar el juego en su modo individual. Y, aunque un servidor no tuvo la oportunidad de probar el modo cooperativo,  si sois un poco más sociales que yo o, simplemente disponéis de un segundo mando, no dudéis en probar con una partida colaborativa, aunque eso suponga no poder culpar a la CPU de las derrotas que sufráis durante el juego.

Volvamos al eje central de la jugabilidad. Como representación del viaje que realizan Nuna y Fox  deberemos avanzar de forma lineal por una multitud de paisajes con el color blanco siempre como protagonista. No faltan los enormes desiertos de hielo, las cavernas rocosas o las antiguas aldeas, cuyos restos descansan bajo las incesantes nevadas. Nuestro objetivo será superar los obstáculos que estos representan, resolviendo los diferentes problemas que surgen en ello y que nos obligan a parar y pensar una manera eficiente de resolverlos. Y esta resulta siempre en la colaboración entre los protagonistas de la historia. Mientras que Fox es más ágil y puede escalar paredes o caminar por las frágiles placas de hielo, Nuna puede agarrar objetos y utilizar su bolera para destruir obstáculos que nos impidan el paso. Otro elemento importante del juego son las constantes ventiscas — logradas con mucho acierto y con una increíble sensación de realidad —  que nos harán trastabillar, e incluso caer, si no nos protegemos de ellas.

Poco tardaremos en descubrir que Fox tiene una conexión especial con la naturaleza que le permite ver a los espíritus que la pueblan y aprovecharnos de su amabilidad (punto para él), para con el zorro, para avanzar por los diferentes escenarios. El problema aquí surge cuando Fox se aleja de ellos, pues estos desaparecen si no esta cerca y Nuna caerá si se encuentra subida en las plataformas en las que se convierten estas criaturas. Es una mecánica que me lleva a pensar, de forma inmediata, en la relación entre ICO y Yorda, del clásico de PS2, ICO, Pues, pese a que ninguna de estas parejas pueden si quiera comunicarse verbalmente entre ellos ni tienen una sola línea de texto en toda la aventura consiguen crear una auténtica sensación de empatía auto impuesta por las mecánicas del juego pero que consigue sentirse natural y cercana.

La, antes mencionada, figura del sabio o cuentacuentos aparece aquí para ocupar ese espacio narrativo que omiten los personajes. Remarcando la sensación de estar viviendo la historia de un cuento, el narrador entona dicha historia siempre con una solemne voz que nos hará sentirnos arropados a la luz de una hoguera en medio de la tundra ártica mientras le escuchamos hablar, absortos. Importantes, y altamente disfrutables, son los momentos en que los espacios narrativos se unen a la jugabilidad y dejas de jugar lo que estás leyendo para vivirlo. Cabe destacar que, aunque la trama sea simple y narrada en una lejana tercera persona, contiene algún que otro giro de guión, que influye sobremanera en su forma de jugar y que ponen las bases a un magnífico final que exige al jugador hacer uso de todo lo aprendido hasta el momento.

En contra de todo lo mencionado hasta ahora, y con cierto odio al redactor por tener que destacar algún aspecto negativo de Never Alone, es que el juego tiene una duración cortísima, que además choca mucho con su precio. Unas tres o cuatro horas (a un precio de 15€), que pese a ser relativas a la habilidad del jugador, difícilmente se verán aumentadas a causa de su escasa dificultad. Podremos alargarlas un poco más, eso sí, si nos centramos en buscar todos los coleccionables del juego, que encontraremos en forma de búhos. Y es algo que recomiendo encarecidamente (y os lo dice el principal detractor de los coleccionables), pues cada uno de estos búhos desbloquearán un fragmento de vídeo, en formato documental, donde nativos  Iñupiaq nos hablarán sobre su cultura y su folclore. Algo que resulta completamente original y que sirve como un fantástico complemento al juego y a su trama. Por otro lado también podemos alargar ese tiempo con su DLC, Foxtales, que abandona los paisajes helados para mostrarnos escenarios mas coloridos y vivos. Sin apartarse del folclore del que hace uso su versión original, Foxtales nos contará otra historia clásica protagonizada por Nuna y Fox, durante la que encontraremos un gran número de puzzles, esta vez más elaborados y difíciles.

Never Alone es el resultado de la unión de los videojuegos y los cuentos. Una unión de elementos narrativos e interactivos que te permite, no solo sentir su historia, si no vivirla de primera mano. Un precioso viaje plagado de determinación, amistad y valor que, además, consigue introducirnos en el folclore iñupiaq y sirve como difusión del mismo. Algo que sin duda es un magnifico gesto hacia —  y desde —  sus habitantes. La travesía de Nuna y Fox enamorará a cualquier jugador que se introduzca en ella y, aunque pueda pecar de ser algo breve, asegura una perfecta tarde libre de invierno, sobretodo si lo acompañáis con una buena bebida caliente.

I recommend this not as a game, but as a great opportunity for education.  As a game alone, I would not have gotten very far, and would be hesitant to recommend it.  However, when examined as a whole, this product delivers on what it sets out to do - and that is bring life to the stories and culture of the Kisima Ingitchuna people.

If you're looking for just gameplay, and don't really feel any excitement over the prospect of learning about a native american culture, then I would say this is probably not a game for you, you would be better off playing something else (Limbo has similar gameplay and is probably a bit more polished when it comes to the gameplay mechanics themselves).  

If you are interested in learning about the Kisima Ingitchuna culture, this will be a unique experience,one that is much more interesting than just walking into a museum.  The Kisima Ingitchuna described themselves as a "living culture", and this game certainly exemplifies that.  I would love it if more native american tribes would create something similar, as this type of storytelling has tremendous potential to bring education and appreciation of native american culture, bringing it to life more than the still displays of a museum could.

26448861.review:
I absolutely loved this game. Granted, it's not very long, but it's fun! I love the story, and the ability to unlock videos so you can learn more about the Iñupiat culture (and these videos relate to what's happening in-game). It's great being able to play through a traditional story and experience it for yourself. The characters are great too, and while there isn't any dialogue besides the narrator, you can get quite attached to Nuna and Fox.

I greatly enjoyed the art-style in-game, as well as the more traditional story-teller drawings in the cutscenes. The portrayal of the spirits was beautiful, and so was the scenery. The music was also well done and fitting for each area.

The weapon in the game can be a bit tricky to aim at times, but once you realize that her free hand will point to where she's aiming, it gets much easier. It's also very interesting to use it and see the video explaining how it was traditionally used.

Arguably, the puzzles weren't always that hard, but for this game I didn't find that to be a mark against it. I've played puzzle gams like Ori and the Blind Forest where, though I loved it, I was sometimes pushed to wanting to throw my controller during some rushed events or puzzles. I liked being able to approach this game with a little less frustration and a bit more consistent enjoyment. The puzzles are enjoyable, and while they can sometimes be a bit of a challenge they won't cause a rage that would cut into the enjoyment of the story being told (or cause such a long stall in gameplay that the flow of the story is lost).

TL;DR: Overall I would give this game a 10/10 - I really enjoyed it! I enjoyed the format that this story was told and being able to be a part of it, and I enjoyed learning about the Iñupiat people. I hope more games like this get made, because this form of combining fun game play with teaching people about a culture's traditions and stories is brilliant!

Side Note: The Foxtales DLC is also fun to play. Really not long at all (much shorter than the main game), but an enjoyable "Epilogue" type story nonetheless. You also get 5 more "Insight" videos looking into the Iñupiat culture and the further underscoring of the theme of "respect for all things"
